ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite unprecedented activity and FDA approval of BTK inhibitors such as ibrutinib (IBR) and acalabrutinib (ACA), and BCL-2 antagonist venetoclax (VEN) for patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), these targeted agents have limitations and do not result in cures as single agents alone. By simultaneous inhibition of pro-survival and proliferative BTK signaling and anti-apoptotic BCL-2 function, we aim to use this combination approach to target high-risk CLL that has poor response to single agents alone. Using a clinical protocol (NCT04169737) combining ACA and VEN, we will analyze pharmacodynamic and molecular endpoints from CLL cells during therapy to evaluate the impact of these drug combinations on efficacy, identify biomarker for response and relapse, and correlate omics changes with biology of the disease.

PHR: Project Narrative: Vision loss is among the top ten disabilities in the United States, with an estimated burden on society of over $35 billion and approximately 285 million people worldwide being visually impaired and 39 million being blind. Many of the causes of vision loss are slow and chronic. We will examine why zebrafish regenerate retinal neurons following a rapid acute damage, but not a slow chronic damage, which may result in the development of novel therapies to restore vision to humans who suffer from chronic retinal degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the current proposal, we will (1) employ innovative Bayesian trajectory analyses with machine-learning techniques to determine if novel strain-based measures of right ventricular (RV) contractile function improves prediction of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) in systemic sclerosis (SSc) by identifying at-risk phenotypes earlier in the disease course, (2) establish the relationship between strain-based measures of RV contractility and contractile reserve with direct pressure-volume hemodynamic chamber-level assessments, and (3) develop a new multivariate algorithm that utilizes innovative imaging based techniques thereby allowing for an early detection strategy that improves upon existing techniques in identifying SSc patients at risk for emerging RV dysfunction and PAH.

PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the result of cellular and network dysfunction at a variety of levels. A key cellular regulator of brain function, astrocytes, are involved in maintenance of synaptic function, neuroinflammation, and the regulation of blood flow to meet the demands of neuronal activity. Astrocytes are intimately connected to other astrocytes, neurons and the vasculature, and communicate through calcium signaling that can be observed through imaging in the brain of living mouse models of AD throughout their lifespan during the progression of AD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) are highly prevalent neurodevelopmental disorders (1 in 44 children) characterized by impairments in social communication and interactions, restricted/repetitive behaviors and abnormal responses to sensory stimuli. Chronic disturbances in gastrointestinal function are often observed in individuals with ASD and are thought to contribute to social impairments and anxiety, yet the underlying disruptions to gastrointestinal-neural circuits in ASD are not known. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the development and function of dorsal root ganglia sensory neurons that innervate the gastrointestinal tract in mouse models for ASD, with the ultimate goal of developing novel treatment strategies to alleviate symptoms associated with peripheral sensory neuron abnormalities and improve ASD phenotypes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cancers, including malignant gliomas, activate molecular processes that protect the ends of chromosomes, called telomeres, over the course of many cycles of cell division. We recently discovered that genetic mutations in the SMARCAL1 gene play a critical role in pathological telomere maintenance in a subset of adult glioblastoma patients. The proposed studies will define the mechanistic role of SMARCAL1 in glioblastoma telomere maintenance and will investigate novel strategies for glioblastoma therapy using cell- based and mouse models of brain tumors.

PHR: NARRATIVE Denervation is strongly implicated in the onset and progressive decline of skeletal muscle mass, composition, and function, termed sarcopenia. By using optogenetics, sophisticated imaging techniques and gene expression analysis, this study will define the mechanisms by which impaired central autonomic network regulation of the peripheral SNS leads to skeletal muscle sympathetic and motor denervation and loss in mass and strength to inform a new approach to attenuate or reverse sarcopenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Black pregnant women are more likely to experience racial discrimination and depressive symptoms and have higher risk for vitamin D deficiency and preterm birth (< 37 completed weeks gestation) compared with White women. Identifying the genomic inflammatory pathways that relate racial discrimination, depressive symptoms and vitamin D deficiency with preterm birth may lead to early identification of risk for preterm birth for Black women, and development of interventions to reduce preterm birth disparities among these women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal creates the largest, best-characterized adult cohort of d-transposition of the great arteries to date in order to explore the structural and functional brain MRI features associated with adult executive function and the potential modulating effects of common genetic variants in neuroresilience and hypoxia genes. Successful completion of this study would be relevant to patients with many types of congenital heart diseases and increase our understanding of prenatal versus adaptive changes associated with altered executive function and may help identify potential pathways for protective versus modifying therapeutic interventions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Americans over age 65 are the largest group of patients and survivors of cancer in the U.S. and are also the most likely to experience sub-optimal treatment outcomes. Assessment of these factors, as part of a clinical exam, can help reduce risk. However, assessment and documentation of age-related risk is not well- coordinated, putting older adults at greater risk, especially diverse older patients such as those with limited English proficiency. The proposed project seeks to examine medical record and multi-level factors that can improve assessment of age-related risk and documentation with a broader goal of improving treatment planning and care for diverse older adults with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The development of novel, effective pharmaceutical compounds is a major public health concern in  light of the rise of antibiotic resistance, the resilience of many types of cancers, and other key health  issues. Addition of fluorine to biologically active molecules, such as drug candidates, can increase the  effectiveness of these molecules by increasing their potency, enabling them to be more easily  absorbed, and modulating how our bodies metabolize them. This research entails the invention of a  novel, mild method for the installment of fluorine to key building blocks and the study of the mechanism  of this chemistry.

PROJECT_TITLE: Copper as a Photocatalyst: Applications in Decarboxylative Fluorination

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dry eye disease is a multifactorial disease of the ocular surface characterized by impaired tear film homeostasis accompanied by ocular symptoms that affects approximately 6.8% of adults in the USA, with a global prevalence as high as 50%. Despite this significant disease burden, there are currently just four FDA- approved therapies for dry eye disease, each targeting only the inflammatory pathway and having limited efficacy. The proposed research will advance novel dry eye disease therapeutics that promote tear fluid secretion by targeting ion transport proteins on epithelial cells lining the ocular surface.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Alterations in the balance of inhibitory and excitatory neurons are thought to underlie diverse neurological disorders including those involving spinal cord such as pain, itch, touch, and sense of limb position. PTF1A and its downstream target PRDM13 are essential regulators of this balance in multiple regions of the nervous system including spinal cord, cerebellum, and retina. Regulatory mechanisms identified here may influence strategies for manipulating the fate of stem cells for regenerative purposes, and are likely to provide fundamental principles of gene regulation common to developing systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Administrative Core of the UK-SRC will continue to promote problem-based, solution-oriented research to reduce exposure and/or negative health impacts associated with exposure to a subclass of persistent halogenated chemicals (e.g. PCBs, TCE, and PFAS). This will be accomplished by using an innovative transdisciplinary research approach that brings together biomedical and environmental scientists, engineers, and trainees using an integrative administrative structure that links together individual projects and cores. The Administrative Core will ensure the continued relevance of the proposed research through bi-directional communication with the SRP and SRP staff, academia, the general public and relevant federal and state communities of practice (e.g. EPA, ATSDR, KYDEP) as well as communities of impact in Appalachia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to environmental chemicals increases the risk of many non-communicable human diseases. The UK- SRC serves our stakeholders and the broader objectives of the Superfund Research Program by conducting studies to understand mechanisms linking exposure to environmental chemicals with human disease risk, lifestyle based approaches to mitigate these risks and strategies for improved sensing and remediation of toxic environmental chemicals. This core component provides UK-SRC investigators with measurements of these environmental chemicals, their metabolites and degradation products and other biological molecules of relevance to human health.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to develop and evaluate a comprehensive group model of well child care for mothers in treatment for opioid use disorder and their children. The healthcare model proposed in this application seeks to positively impact key healthcare and health outcomes by addressing critical gaps in parenting knowledge, behaviors, and engagement in care. This line of research will have broad applicability to communities and health care systems affected by high rates of maternal opioid use disorder; if implemented at scale this model has potential to substantially impact early childhood outcomes, serving as a critical role in mitigating the intergenerational impact of the opioid crisis.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Group well child care intervention for infants of mothers in treatment for opioid use disorder

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Data Management and Analysis Core (DMAC) of the University of Kentucky Superfund Research Center (UK-SRC) provides an integral new resource by functioning as a nexus for interactions across projects and cores. It systematically integrates data assets through the entire lifecycle of the grant and facilitates interaction of investigators and trainees to assist them in conducting research that addresses Superfund mandates. The DMAC will foster data sharing within and beyond UK-SRC, including researchers, as well as community stakeholders, and governmental agencies committed to protecting public health from the adverse effects of hazardous chemicals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco use and secondhand smoke exposure (SHSe) represent critical health disparities in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs); Armenia (AM) and Georgia (GE) represent the 11th and 6th highest smoking rates in men globally (51.5% and 55.5%, respectively), but have low rates of smoking in women (1.8% and 7.8%) and few smoke-free homes (SFHs; 38.6%), which can reduce SHSe and tobacco use rates. This proposal builds on our ongoing collaborations with national public health organizations in AM and GE and advancements in local public health infrastructure; we aim to adapt our team’s evidence-based SFH intervention for homes in AM and GE, develop capacity to deliver the intervention via local community partners and the national quitlines, and test the intervention in a hybrid effectiveness-implementation RCT. This work will advance our long-term goals of building the knowledge base informing strategies to reduce global tobacco-related disparities, as well as the implementation and scale-out of evidence-based interventions in LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Community Engagement Core (CEC) works to achieve public health benefits within communities and  supports the UK-SRC by encouraging Superfund Research Program (SRP) stakeholders to protect their health  from exposure to environmental contaminants by consuming a healthy diet and increasing physical activity to  reduce the bodily amount and toxicity of hazardous substances (mandate #4). The proposed CEC prevention/  intervention activities are community-driven, solution-oriented programs that translate the science of the UK-  SRC and addresses the needs of SRP stakeholders with concerns regarding exposure to hazardous  substances. The CEC programs achieve this by providing community residents with the opportunity to improve  nutrition, increase physical activity and enhance environmental health literacy among community residents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of this proposal is to investigate a mechanism used by macrophages to label and detect target cells including cancer cells, pathogenic cells in inflammatory conditions, fibroblasts in fibrotic diseases and peritoneal adhesions, persistently infected cells, smooth muscle cells in atherosclerosis, and in cells reaching the end of their lifespan. We found that activated macrophages secrete a soluble form of calreticulin (CRT) that binds to asialoglycans thereby forming an ‘eat me’ signal on the surface of cancer cells or the other cells listed above that are then recognized and removed by phagocytosis. We will investigate the biochemical pathways leading to CRT secretion from macrophages and to asialoglycan exposure on the surface of target cells, and examine the scenarios in which this mechanism is utilized and may have therapeutic implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project explores connections between two major public health concerns that are highly relevant to Superfund Research Program (SRP) stakeholders and the SRP: widespread contamination of the environment by a class of long-lasting toxic chemical contaminants known as PCBs and PFAS. These contaminants have been linked to a leading U.S. health challenge, cardiovascular diseases, and also linked to the liver and gut. The project addresses specifically SRP Mandate 4 by testing dietary interventions that may disrupt disease processes by stabilizing the gut bacteria and liver and reducing cardiovascular risks initiated by exposure to pollutants, particularly in people who reside near Superfund or other hazardous waste sites where PCBs and other pollutants are prevalent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE STATEMENT Research described in this application will validate tools for determining chain flipping rate constants in AHL quorum signal synthase enzymes. This information is critical to achieve selectivity in quorum sensing inhibition. Small molecules that selectively modulate quorum sensing will provide valuable leads for developing novel antivirulent compounds in antibacterial therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Once a T cell reaches a site of infection, the cell must decide how long to reside there before returning to circulation. This “stay or go” decision shapes the immediate response to infection, as well the type of memory response that is established. Here, we will address how T cells are drawn out of inflamed tissues, as well as track the fate of the cells that have left these tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and diabetes are at epidemic levels, and the toxicity of environmental contaminants during perinatal development could be a significant contributor to these trends. The proposed studies will offer innovative new insights to understanding the role of exercise in mitigating the health impacts of in utero contaminant exposures. Project 2 clearly addresses three of the Superfund Research Program primary objectives: Mandate 1, “advanced techniques for detection, assessment and evaluation of the effect of hazardous substances on human health”, Mandate 2, “methods to assess the risks to human health presented by hazardous substances”, and Mandate 4, “methods to reduce the amount and toxicity of hazardous substances.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knowledge about the dispersal of Plasmodium falciparum parasites is essential for the design of effective interventions to to control malaria. The proposed work leverages new genomic methods to conduct a comparative analysis of approaches to study spatial movement of parasites and transmission chains in low and high transmission settings, where different methods may be necessary. The proposed award will support the development of a research platform that employs translational genomics to improve our understanding of parasite biology, inform interventions for malaria control and elimination, and supports the career development of both the investigator and his trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The persistence of toxic pollutants at Superfund sites poses a major environmental public health problem and a serious need for environmental solutions to reduce risk. Our research is expected to lead to cost-effective technologies for remediation of chemicals, such as TCE, PCE and PCBs, to nontoxic and biodegradable intermediates and for superfast sorption of PFAS compounds with responsive polymer materials. Our approaches to develop new polymer membrane and 2D-based materials to detoxify water and low energy consuming adsorption/desorption technologies should lead to an advanced technology solution in the field of remediation science and engineering from Superfund sites to water utility companies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this project is to advance fate and transport research to identify and reduce exposure risks associated with trichloroethene (TCE), tetrachloroethene (PCE), and PFAS. Field study results verify and calibrate new models that predict contaminant mass flux associated with damaged subsurface piping networks, which serve as preferential pathways for contaminants to be transported throughout communities. Evidence- based practices serve as a framework to promote environmental health literacy, so that community stakeholders, representatives from regulatory agencies, and industry groups can provide information to develop solutions that will ensure Superfund mandates are addressed and public health is protected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: There is intense interest in identifying innate immune mechanisms, such as Complement, that are involved in controlling viruses, particularly those which establish persistent or prolonged infections. Our work on C’ resistance during persistent infections will have strong potential to inform future therapeutics, given: 1) the long-standing clinical impact of prolonged respiratory infections, 2) that polymorphisms in C’ genes can correlate with severity of viral infections (39, 42) and 3) that new clinical trials are underway with drugs that modulate C’ responses. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The overarching goal of this application is to develop a single “pan-respiratory” mRNA-encoded Cas13 drug for treating viral respiratory infections, but with a focus on the three most impactful respiratory viruses in circulation, RSV, influenza and SARS-CoV-2. Multiple Cas13 nucleases will be evaluated, and mechanisms of action investigated; efficacy will be demonstrated with all three pathogens in rodent infection, co-infection and transmission models. Overall, we feel this approach and RNA-based platform have the potential to alter the paradigm for how viral infections are treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Rhythm perception is a core part of music processing and is central to music’s positive effect on a variety of neurological disorders, including Parkinson’s disease and dyslexia. Musical rhythm perception involves auditory-motor interactions which are not well understood at the circuit level. Our goal is to leverage the extensive knowledge of auditory and motor circuits in songbirds and behavioral methods for studying rhythm perception to investigate the contributions of motor regions to auditory rhythm processing.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reward seeking is normally suppressed in inappropriate conditions, whereas opioid use and seeking often occur despite negative health and societal consequences. Activity in paraventricular thalamic neurons that project to the nucleus accumbens provides top-down inhibitory control over natural reward seeking, but the influence of opioid use on activity in this pathway is unknown. Here we determine the influence of opioid use on activity and plasticity in projection-specific paraventricular thalamic neurons and neuronal ensembles, and further determine the function of this pathway for suppression and expression of opioid-seeking behaviors.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Crosby, Gregory J. Narrative Delirium is the most common complication of surgery and anesthesia in older patients and is associated with serious morbidity, including accelerated decline to dementia. Using biomarkers in plasma as well as MR imaging of cerebral volume, this proposal will investigate occult cerebral neurodegeneration pathology characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders as a risk factor for postoperative delirium, and whether surgery- induced inflammation and delirium lead to neural injury that accelerates neurodegeneration and cognitive decline. By elucidating mechanisms of and plasma biomarkers for postoperative delirium, this work will help improve risk prediction and the cognitive outcomes of vulnerable older surgical patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shiftwork is now recognized as a risk factor for type 2 diabetes, yet the mechanisms underlying these associations are poorly understood. Herein, we will test the hypothesis that real-world nightshift work impairs whole-body metabolic flexibility across the 24h day-night cycle, and that this will be associated with disrupted skeletal muscle clocks. To test this hypothesis, we will conduct rigorously controlled in-patient studies to assess and compare whole-body metabolic flexibility using innovative 24h metabolic chamber protocols, as well as skeletal muscle clock function by comparing diurnal shifts in skeletal muscle clock genes, in dayshift versus nightshift workers.

PHR: Project Narrative The IUSM Graduate Division has committed significant resources and focused effort in order to increase the diversity of our applicant pool and enrolled students. The central mission of IMSD at IUSM Training Program will be to provide graduate students with a holistic training experience that enriches their technical, operational and professional skills. The specific goals of the program include to increase the number of students that obtain independent fellowships, increase PhD completion rates, decrease time-to-degree, and provide transferable curricular content.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public health relevance Genome instability is a hallmark a wide range of disease-states including cancer and neurologic conditions. Over two dozen neurodegenerative, musculoskeletal, and neurological disorders are caused by triplet repeat expansions, the mechanisms of which are not well understood. The studies proposed here will provide a deeper understanding of the crosstalk between DNA repair pathways and the impact of this crosstalk on repeat expansion and will also yield novel mechanistic insights into the function of enzymes that modulate repeat expansion, and will thus have wide-ranging biomedical implications.

PHR: Older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias are increasingly likely to be discharged to a skilled nursing facility after hospitalization for a serious injury or illness. Transitions from one health care setting to another are a precarious time for cognitively impaired patients who are at risk of inappropriate hospital readmissions and medication errors, among other potential adverse outcomes. By investigating the characteristics, health care utilization, and health outcomes of cognitively impaired patients who experience multiple transitions from home to hospital to a skilled nursing facility to home, we can design interventions that improve the quality of care and health outcomes for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Host innate immune response plays a crucial role in combating infections. This study will elucidate new antibacterial functions of two interferon stimulated genes, OAS1 and OASL. The discovery of OAS proteins' role in antibacterial host defense will have a broader implication for human infectious diseases and the development of new treatments against antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections. In addition, our findings may provide a link between OAS1 polymorphisms and human infectious and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The incidence of coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), caused by the highly infectious soil fungi Coccidioides posadasii and C. immitis, has been rapidly growing for decades with current statistics estimating 150,000 new cases annually in the United States. Serological diagnosis is the most common method, typically detecting the presence of antibodies (four tests on the market) or antigens (one test on the market), and both types of diagnostic tests are based on intellectual property owned by companies and thus no commercial provider of antigens or antibodies is available. Advanced diagnostic development approaches can help improve our ability to detect and diagnose infection and we propose to use both well-validated methodologies and innovative novel approaches to improve Valley Fever diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The research included in this proposal will improve our understanding of disease mechanisms that contribute to the health burden of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Studying multiple mutations with divergent effects on molecular function and developing quantitative modeling tools to predict resultant changes in molecular and cellular force generation and cellular remodeling will set the stage for a more precise categorization of and search for new individualized therapeutics for patients with different HCM genotypes. Finally, advanced knowledge on the effects of altered forces on cardiac fibroblast phenotype and extracellular remodeling will provide greater insight into the role of secondary tissue remodeling (fibrosis) that contributes to HCM disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Enormous unexplained differences in speech recognition outcomes are observed for both newly implanted and experienced adult cochlear implant (CI) users. This project aims to determine how specific attributes of the auditory-social environment impact speech recognition abilities in new CI users, and how their environments change following implantation. Findings will identify factors that are potentially modifiable and reflect the everyday, real-world experience of adult CI users, setting the groundwork for accounting for them in clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Heart failure imposes a tremendous morbidity and mortality burden, costing the U.S. healthcare system over $31 billion per year. An under-recognized and yet important contributor to heart failure outcomes is right ventricular dysfunction, which remains understudied due to technical issues that have historically challenged conventional approaches to cardiovascular imaging. We will examine how deep learning models can precisely evaluate right ventricular function – and enable earlier, more accurate assessments of its contributions to cardiovascular risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The function and regulation of mammalian RNAi machinery in the context of antiviral immunity has remained poorly understood mainly because the RNAi machinery in mammals also regulates basic cellular function, making it impossible to manipulate the RNAi gene expression without causing developmental defects or lethality. We have recently succeeded in uncoupling human RNAi’s functions in antiviral immunity and in development by re-producing the antiviral activity of human RNAi machinery in Caenorhabditis elegans nematodes. Findings from the proposed research will not only advance our understanding on how the antiviral activity of human RNAi machinery is regulated but also facilitate the development of novel therapeutic strategy for treatment of viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Establishing how combinations of broadly HIV-neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) with different epitope specificities can be most effectively used to cover HIV variants would have significant impact on the development of approaches to prevent or treat HIV infection. This project will uniquely focus on, and determine, the reactivity of single virions with multiple bnAb classes in situ. The data will fill key information gaps in the process of deciding how to best use bnAb combinations for HIV prevention and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will directly address a persistent puzzle in developmental gene regulation: how do newly active developmental transcription factors bind and activate their target enhancers, when they are tightly wrapped by nucleosomes that prevent transcription factor binding in the first place? The experiments proposed to solve this puzzle will not only leverage cutting edge molecular technologies to probe the dynamics of transcription factor- chromatin conflicts, but will also probe whether there are biological rationales for the persistence of these conflicts, such as for the maintenance of developmental fidelity across variable metabolic contexts that are commonly experienced in vivo. In summary, the proposed project will improve our understanding of the function of chromatin as a regulator of cell fate that can be applied across myriad developmental and disease contexts, and will integrate this understanding of molecular regulation with our broader understanding of cellular metabolic state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is associated with bronchiolitis, pneumonia and flu-like syndromes, as well as asthma exacerbations, and it is considered a serious public health problem, for which no effective treatment or vaccine is currently available, while many fundamental questions regarding the pathogenesis of its associated lung disease still need to be answered. This project seeks to investigate novel molecular mechanisms regulating host cell responses following infection with RSV. In the long term, our studies could lead to new pharmacologic strategies to prevent or treat serious lower respiratory tract infections, therefore reducing RSV- associated morbidity and mortality.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Altered sensory processing is the hallmark of most psychiatric conditions, from schizophrenia to autism,  but to this date, it remains unknown how sensory information is processed in the brain and to which extend  perception is influenced by our emotional state. By studying how visual information is integrated and  shaped by internal factors, this project will increase our understanding of the fundamental processing  underlying healthy sensory experience. The outcomes of this project will shed the light on new approaches  and paradigms to investigate pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Molecular Biophysics seeks to define the basic underpinning of health and disease by obtaining a quantitative description of the shapes and surface features of molecules, and the network of interactions between the many thousands of molecules that bring cells to life. Our training program provides a highly enriching environment for educating scientists in the language and implementation of Molecular Biophysics so that it can be applied to the most critical questions in medicine and biology. By fostering the development of a cadre of diverse and highly-skilled quantitative scientists, our program will contribute in a significant way to understanding human physiology and the malfunctions that lead to disease, which in turn can be used to develop new approaches and technologies to address the critical challenges at the forefront of biomedical science.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to human health because cells sense changes in their environment through signaling processes that occur at the plasma membrane which defines the cell surface. This work seeks to decipher how heterogeneous membranes fundamentally contribute to cell sensing in broad functional contexts, with the ultimate goal of providing researchers with novel strategies for the treatment of disease. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to seeking fundamental knowledge that will help to prevent and treat these human illnesses.

PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance—Overall Program The identification of genetic contributors to cancer will help identify high-risk groups and support the development of new treatments, as well as refine prevention and screening guidelines. However, even with our current knowledge of susceptibility genes and the expected novel discoveries, there are significant barriers to getting genetic counseling and testing, particularly in the African American population. Until we can overcome these barriers, the implementation of clinical testing will be difficult, therefore the development of novel strategies to overcome barriers to testing will be essential in reducing cancer burden and health disparities.

PHR: Project Narrative Variants of uncertain significance (VUS) in known cancer susceptibility genes are more commonly identified in African Americans compared to whites, and there is a need for innovative approaches to characterizing potentially clinically actionable VUS. Identifying novel pathogenic mutations in known cancer susceptibility genes will improve our ability to provide targeted prevention and treatment options for African Americans with hereditary cancers, and defining the genomic landscape of cancer susceptibility in African Americans will improve identification of high-risk individuals who would benefit from enhanced surveillance and precision treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will investigate the role of inherited genetic susceptibility as well as select environmental risk factors with the development of multiple primary cancers (MPCs) in African Americans first diagnosed with female breast, prostate or colorectal cancer. We will discover new knowledge about factors underlying MPCs in African Americans, a population experiencing excess cancer morbidity and mortality. This information will inform future screening, prevention, and risk-mitigation strategies and ultimately lessen the cancer burden in this high risk population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop a legal dataset of vaccine consent laws for minors and to model the interplay between these laws and the spread and mortality of COVID-19, leveraging the power of nationally representative data and an agent-based simulation. The project team consists of a group of interdisciplinary researchers and community partners, allowing for a rigorous understanding of the impact of vaccine consent laws and the implications of potential interventions to increase vaccine update in adolescents. We will use an agent-based simulation to model the effects of vaccine consent laws and other real-world effects (e.g., vaccine hesitancy rates) in different locations to provide researchers with valuable information to inform future policy decisions and intervention development and implementation.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Mitochondrial disease impacts 1 in 5000 adults and causes a range of negative effects on the nervous system, heart, eye, ear, kidney, blood and muscle and healthy aging. One reason we have few treatments and no cures has been the lack of animal models of these often devastating diseases. The purpose of this project is to make the first collection using custom programmed mitochondrial DNA variants of human clinical cases in the pioneering animal model, the zebrafish. Together, these in vivo avatars made using new mitochondrial gene editing technologies will enable new approaches for diagnoses and therapies for these terrible diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory diseases account for approximately a quarter of all pediatric clinical consultations and hospital admissions in the United States, and pneumonia is the leading cause of death in children worldwide. There remains a critical shortage of trained investigators in pediatric respiratory diseases in the United States, despite clear evidence that the onset of lung disease in childhood is a strong predictor for respiratory disease in later life and prevention and/or treatment of childhood respiratory diseases has the potential to significantly reduce disease and medical costs associated with disease in later life. Our T32 training program in the Eudowood Division of Respiratory Sciences at Johns Hopkins University, now in its 20th year, has a strong track record of success in preparing young investigators who can discover novel mechanisms to improve diagnosis and treatment of pediatric respiratory diseases, attain career development funding, and transition into independent leaders within the field.

PROJECT_TITLE: Multidisciplinary Training Program in Pediatric Pulmonary
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM (OA)]

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a highly aggressive sub-type of breast cancer that is characterized by poor survival, early spread of cancer cells to other organs, and a relative lack of therapies which specifically target cancer cells. This goal of this project is to develop a more effective strategy to treat TNBC by targeting specific receptors found on tumor cells, using targeted radionuclide treatments that destroy cancer cells, but are not harmful to normal tissue. To achieve this goal, we will develop a theranostic targeting peptide that will specifically deliver cytotoxic levels of radiation dose precisely to TNBC; this targeting peptide will be optimized, validated, and then tested for imaging and treatment in TNBC mouse models.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is an important but extremely understudied human pathogen causing significant clinical problems worldwide including numerous extrahepatic manifestations. We will identify the underlying mechanisms of hepatitis E virus extrahepatic pathogenesis through infection of neuronal cells in vitro and in a rodent animal model during HEV infection. The information obtained from this project will inform potential therapeutic targets for HEV-associated neurological sequelae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE As we age, we accumulate “senescent” cells which have a detrimental effect on various organs and tissues, including the immune system, which limits our ability to fight off infections. In this proposal, a team of experts on the biology of aging and immune responses to pathogens combine forces to determine which populations of senescent cells are responsible for these effects, the components of the immune system that they compromise – and how these detrimental effects can be reversed by elimination of senescent cells, using defined and novel therapeutics.

PHR: Project Narrative This training program is in its 29ᵗʰ year, and has trained 126 fellows in transdisciplinary approaches to cancer prevention and control. Over 80% of trainees are in research positions, and approximately 30% of trainees have come from underrepresented minority (URM) backgrounds (38% in current cycle). The maturity of this Program, extensive resources available through Harvard and synergy across the focal training areas provide an outstanding platform for training the next generation of cancer prevention scientists.
PROJECT_TERMS: Cancer Control;cancer prevention;Education;programs
PROJECT_TITLE: The Harvard Chan Education Program in Cancer Prevention and Control
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Institutional Training and Education Study Section (F)[NCI-F]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physician scientists play an important role in addressing the prevention and management of heart, lung, blood, and sleep disorders through research whose findings can advance the development of new diagnostic, treatment, and prevention strategies. The goal of this renewal proposal is to continue to provide medical students with skills and knowledge in translational research through mentored research experiences at the University of Alabama at Birmingham that are concentrated in heart, lung, and/or blood fields and through didactics. The impact of the program will be the development of a diverse group of highly motivated, well-trained, early physician scientists who are interested in and motivated for pursuing an academic medicine career involving heart, lung, and/or blood research.

PHR: RUTGERS CANCER INSTITUTE OF NEW JERSEY PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The catchment area of Rutgers Cancer Institute of New Jersey (CINJ) is the state of New Jersey (NJ), with a diverse population of over 9.2 million. In 2019, NJ ranked 6th in cancer incidence rates nationwide with 483.7 cases per 100,000 (54,271 cases). CINJ is the State of New Jersey's only National Cancer Institute (NCI)- designated Comprehensive Cancer Center. The mission of CINJ is to reduce the burden of cancer by advancing cancer research, prevention, screening and education for the most densely-populated and one of the most ethnically and socioeconomically diverse states in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to understand why some children with single ventricle heart disease fail after surgical procedures. Currently, images from echocardiography, catheterizations, and cardiovascular magnetic resonance are being used to qualitatively choose the best surgical approach for these patients. In this project, we aim to quantitatively determine the most optimal surgical repair for each patient by simulating different surgical repairs and comparing the post-surgical hemodynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Unfortunately, it is challenging to achieve and maintain adequate immunosuppression over time for kidney transplant patients due to variation in the blood levels of immunosuppressive medications. This study will determine if variations in the microbes in the stool are associated with blood levels of immunosuppressive medication named mycophenolate mofetil. We will also determine if variations in the microbes in the human body lead to higher blood levels of this medication and thereby explain the side effects of this medication seen commonly in kidney transplant patients.

ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Diabetes is a pandemic, emerging as one of the most prevalent diseases among people aged 20 years and older in the United States. The demographics of veteran population fall in this age group. In those, 25% are afflicted with diabetes. Currently, a significant proportion of VA health care resources are devoted to older veterans, whom constitute over 45% of the patients. The cost of diabetes in the US in 2017 was $327 billion and VA spends $1.5 billion annually. Diabetic nephropathy (DN) is the leading cause of end stage renal disease (ESRD) accounting for 44% new cases each year. Current therapies only delay the progression to ESRD and do not arrest the disease. Therefore, there is urgent need for new therapeutic approaches for DN. This proposal will explore the therapeutic modality of a newly identified translational variant of PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted in chromosome 10), PTEN-Long, in rodent models of DN. Also, its role in activation of platelet- derived growth factor receptor-b for progression of DN will be investigated.

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Disturbances in motivation are major determinants of poor functional outcome in a large number of Veterans with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Despite their clear public health significance, available treatments for these motivational disturbances are minimally effective. To facilitate treatment development, this translational research project will investigate four subcomponents of an affective neuroscience model of motivation: Reward Receipt, Reward anticipation, Effort Valuation, and Goal-directed action selection. We will test hypothesized differences between schizophrenia (n = 60), bipolar disorder (n = 60), and control (n = 60) groups on functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging and behavioral motivation tasks that assess these four subcomponents. We will also examine relations between performance on these tasks and community functioning. Results will help specify brain-based reward-processing impairments that contribute to motivational disturbances, and guide both clinical and preclinical studies of new treatments.

PHR: Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a rare, cholestatic liver disease characterized by bile duct stricturing, biliary senescence and liver fibrosis, and can be complicated by cirrhosis, portal hypertension and microcirculatory disturbances that increase mortality risks in these patients. U.S. Veterans have increased incidences of liver disease and cirrhosis, that can be coupled with portal hypertension, which leads to enhanced morbidity and mortality in this demographic. The goal of this proposal is to demonstrate that endothelin (ET) signaling, mediated by transforming growth factor (TGF)-β1 that can, in turn, enhance ET expression, increases biliary senescence and liver vascular angiogenesis through autocrine and paracrine mechanisms. Furthermore, targeting ET/TGF-β signaling may prove therapeutic for the treatment of PSC.

PHR: The CDC estimates more than 30 million Americans have chronic kidney disease (CKD), with a disproportionate burden on U.S. Veterans (prevalence a third higher than the general population), and we have no sustainable therapeutic strategies to prevent or reverse CKD. As such, the Department of Veterans Affairs and the current White House administration underscored the importance of new therapeutics. Podocytes are epithelial cells in the kidney whose major function is the maintenance of the kidney filtration barrier to prevent CKD. Injury to podocytes has been implicated in many glomerular diseases, but therapies targeting podocyte dysfunction are limited. Our proposal will address this current gap in the field by developing an integrated framework to optimize lead novel small molecule agonists to a critical regulator of gene expression (Krüppel- Like Factor 15) and test their therapeutic role in preclinical proteinuric models. Therefore, the studies we propose are highly significant and clinically relevant to the Department of Veterans Affairs.

PHR: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a life threatening disease that kills thousands of Americans each year including Veterans. We have recently demonstrated that the protein mammalian target of rapamycin 2 (MTORC2) is constitutively activated in human AML cell lines and primary patient materials. Here we will study how this occurs and determine if inhibiting MTORC2 will lead to better therapy for AML.

ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: It is estimated that 14% of the general population in the US live with chronic kidney disease (CKD); however, the prevalence of CKD in veterans is 34% higher compared to the general population. One of the main challenges in CKD is impaired phosphate homeostasis. Given the considerable negative sequelae associated with hyperphosphatemia, such as increased cardiovascular mortality, reducing plasma phosphate is a critical goal of therapy. Renal phosphate reabsorption is mediated by the sodium- phosphate cotransporters Npt2a and Npt2c. The former mediates the majority of renal phosphate reabsorption (~75%). We identified that pharmacological inhibition of Npt2a, via a novel orally absorbable Npt2a inhibitor, causes phosphaturia, reductions in plasma phosphate levels and suppression of parathyroid hormone, but also increases urinary excretion of sodium and chloride. Our studies will provide critical insight if Npt2a inhibition will improve phosphate homeostasis and hypertension in CKD.

PHR: Gastric cancer is a devastating disease with poor prognosis. The risk for gastric cancer in the general population of the United States is low; however, certain ethnic, racial, and immigrant groups are at much higher risk. There is a need for better tools to identify these high-risk individuals in order to improve outcomes from gastric cancer.

PHR: In response to RFA-DA-19-018, we propose to maintain and enhance the established medication development infrastructure at Virginia Commonwealth University Institute for Drug and Alcohol Studies (IDAS) to support Phase I and Phase 2 clinical trials in collaboration with the Division of Therapeutics and Medical Consequences at NIDA. As a demonstration project of the ability of IDAS to conduct early phase clinical trials, we propose to assess safety, target engagement, and preliminary measures of efficacy, for the serotonin 2C receptor agonist lorcaserin in combination with buprenorphine for opioid use disorder.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center (LCCC) forms the nexus for researchers focused on understanding and identifying the mechanisms leading to, the prevention of, and treatments for cancer. LCCC is an integral component of the research mission at The University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill, coalescing the cancer research capabilities of the Schools of Medicine, Public Health, Pharmacy, and Nursing, and the College of Arts and Sciences. The LCCC strives to reduce cancer incidence, morbidity, and mortality in North Carolina, the United States and across the globe through innovative research, cutting-edge treatments, multi-disciplinary training, education and outreach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative for Genetic Code Expansion Center The Genetic Code Expansion Biomedical Technology Development and Dissemination Center will allow biomedical researchers around the world to have access to better scientific tools to generate specially designed forms of proteins for probing and visualizing how life works. This will help them better determine how and where biological processes go wrong to cause cancer, heart disease, pain, diabetes, Parkinson's disease, and many other diseases, and will also drive new innovations and enable the development of more sensitive and specific diagnostic tests and more effective drugs.

PHR: Loss of muscle mass occurs in many diseases or as a consequence of aging. It is associated with loss of independence, risk for illness, as well as death, and it may disproportionately affect veterans compared to the general population because of their age and disabling medical conditions from military service. Aside from exercise, there are no current therapies. In this project, we elucidate a gene switch controlling muscle mass. Insights from these studies may identify a therapeutic pathway to halt or reverse muscle loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This new application requests funding to support an Initiative for Maximizing Student Development (IMSD) T32 at Emory University that will support graduate students from groups historically excluded and underrepresented in biomedical science at an early stage of graduate training to position them for success. We propose activities to support graduate training by building scientific identity and resilience while embracing research excellence through an engaged, supportive, and diverse IMSD community. Training activities, which will complement but not duplicate, discipline-specific requirements will: include evidence-based learning approaches, train students in scientific writing through a formal course, ensure training in rigor and reproducibility, mandate mentor training for all faculty mentors, build mentoring and professional networks, and emphasize career/professional development with the goal of contributing to student success and a diverse biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This program addresses an important societal need to increase the number of individuals from underrepresented backgrounds who enter and complete doctoral training in the biomedical and behavioral sciences. We propose to accomplish this goal through exposure to cutting-edge research experiences, broad mentorship support, and targeted educational and professional development activities that prepare students to succeed in Ph.D. or MD- PhD programs and enhance diversity in the Biomedical Research Workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Ralston, Penny A. Project Narrative African Americans have higher heart disease and stroke-related morbidity and mortality in comparison to Non- Hispanic Whites and other ethnic/racial groups. Church-based health interventions have shown improvement in health behaviors and clinical outcomes, yet there is limited research available that evaluates the extent to which churches themselves can implement these interventions. This proposed project will determine the effectiveness of HHUC implementation strategies in relation to process outcomes and reducing CVD risk in African Americans, examining two possible strategies. PHR: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the world’s 2nd leading cause of cancer-related death and one of the fastest-growing cancers in the US; 85% of patients die within 5 years, mainly due to late detection, limited treatment options, and high recurrence. This project is to develop a robust evidence-based urine biospecimen practice for sample collection, processing, and long-term storage will lead to the validation of urine tests for assessing HCC treatment in clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acidosis is common in critically ill pneumonia patients and is associated with high mortality. Carbonic anhydrase IX (CA IX) is a critical determinant of pulmonary microvascular endothelial cell (PMVEC) acid regulation, metabolism and migration, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection induces cytotoxic amyloid production that induces soluble CA IX shedding from PMVECs. In this project, we test the hypothesis that Pseudomonas aeruginosa induces production of cytotoxic amyloids which leads to CA IX shedding from PMVECs that increases lung injury, with the goal of identifying biomarkers and therapeutic targets for pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative DNA damage caused by environmental genotoxicants will result in mutations and disease if not repaired rapidly and accurately. Homology directed repair (HDR) is an essential mechanism of faithful DNA repair, but our understanding of it is limited because prior studies have largely used models of embryonic development, cell culture, or cancer. We have developed a model of Brca1/HDR deficiency in adult mice to determine how HDR preserves viability and maintains genome integrity in various tissues after exposure to different types of DNA damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Certain diseases of the central nervous system are caused by cells of the immune system that attack neurons. It is thought that these immune cells originate from the blood and infiltrate the brain. In this grant, we propose to test the hypothesis that the bone marrow of the skull is actually the major source of some of these immune cells, which infiltrate the nervous system through the meninges, reside there and eventually develop into autoreactive cells that cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT There are currently over 110,000 patients on the organ transplant waiting list in the US, a number that far exceeds the supply of available organs. A major reason is the limitations of our current organ preservation technology, which disallows the transplantation of marginally injured organs and limits preservation duration. This project aims to improve public health by developing a protocol to bank organs for several weeks up to a few months, enabling global organ matching and potentially utilization of organs unusable with current technology.

PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a common cause of morbidity in the veteran population. According to the NIH Consensus Development Panel on Rehabilitation of Persons with TBI, an estimated 2.5-6.5 million Americans live with TBI-related disabilities. The long term consequences of TBI may extend beyond the associated neuro- cognitive deficits as recent studies have indicated that the risk of cardiovascular mortality is markedly increased in subjects with a history of TBI. This mortality risk is associated with increased plaque build-up in the arteries suggesting that TBI promotes atherosclerosis. However, the causal relationship between TBI and vascular disease is not clear. If there is a causal relationship between TBI and vascular disease, this will have immediate implications for preventive therapies. The goal of this proposal is to validate the causal relationship and mechanisms involved in vascular disease associated with TBI. Potential therapies will also be tested. Results of these studies may lead to novel strategies to reduce vascular events in subjects with TBI.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: This project is of high relevance to the public health. Recently, the highly virulent strain of human fungal pathogen, Candida auris, has emerged as an important healthcare-associated microbe that has rapidly disseminated to multiple countries including the United States. This yeast is particularly concerning because it is often resistant to commonly used antifungal drugs, with some strains exhibiting resistance to all currently available classes of medication. Although outbreaks of Candida auris have only begun to be reported in VA patient populations, our patients have many of the risk factors for infection that have been identified in recent cohorts. These include hospitalization, particularly in ICUs, prior antibiotic exposure, immunosuppression, invasive procedures or indwelling catheters, and residence in assisted living or long-term care facilities. Our project aims to define factors associated with infection with Candida auris to better identify veterans and patients at risk of infection and persistent colonization.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The search for improved therapeutics to treat depression and other psychiatric illnesses has frequently been complicated by a need to simultaneously engage multiple downstream targets in order to achieve suitable efficacy. Presently, our understanding of ketamine's ability to act as an antidepressant is complicated by the potential of its active metabolite, hydroxynorketamine, to act through a different mechanism from the parent compound itself. This project aims to track emergent effects arising from the simultaneous actions of ketamine and hydroxynorketamine in the brain as a means to develop improved multi-target antidepressants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing number of patients are surviving Acute Respiratory Failure (ARF), but may experience long-lasting psychological problems after returning home. Early, evidenced-based treatment to reduce psychological symptoms in the intensive care unit and hospital may help improve patient outcomes, but research evaluating such treatment for ARF patients is scant. This project includes qualitative research that tailors an existing psychological intervention for use in ARF patients, then subsequently conducts a pilot randomized controlled trial to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and potential benefit of the psychological intervention on ARF patients’ anxiety and associated outcomes at hospital discharge and 3-month follow-up.

PHR: The heritability of complex traits, including disease, is governed by a complex interplay of many genetic variants. This project will produce unique datasets and tools that will reveal how groups of genes interact with each other and how networks of genetic interactions are rewired in response to different genetic backgrounds. The genetic interaction maps produced by the project will provide insights into gene function, an overall view of the functional organization of a human cell and provide a template for understanding the link between genotype and phenotype, including the genetic basis of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Proton therapy is more effective on attacking tumors compared to conventional therapy with photons, however, the risk of damaging healthy tissue surrounding the cancerous region is higher. Monitoring where in the patient the radiation dose is being deposited is challenging for certain regions of the body with high density heterogeneity, such as the lungs, with significant respiratory motion, like liver, or where extreme precision is needed to avoid toxicity in critical neighbor organs, such as in head and neck cancers. In this project, we aim to test the novel Cerenkov charge induction (CCI) thallium bromide (TlBr) detectors for real time monitoring of proton therapy in the challenging scenarios described before.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Hispanic youth are nearly three times as likely to be at high risk for developmental delays compared to white non-Hispanic children because of disproportionate exposure to early adversity, which is biologically embedded via epigenomic changes. This study aims to understand how changing social context alters the epigenome among at-risk young Hispanic children and potentially ameliorates the biological embedding of adversity. We will also examine epigenomic biosignatures of response to early intervention that will result in innovative approaches to risk identification, the advancement of personalized prevention and intervention, and, ultimately, to a reduction of health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: While UV light causes many mutations during the development of skin cancers like melanoma, most driver mutations that contribute to disease progression do not display traditional characteristics of being caused by UV damage. This proposal will investigate the formation and mutagenic potential of rare atypical photoproducts at TA, CA, and AC dinucleotides in response to physiologically relevant UVB light, assess whether such lesions are sensitive to photo-reactivation by cyclobutane pyrimidine dimer and 6-4 photoproduct photolyases, utilize novel methods to map the location of TA photoproducts across genomes, and determine which DNA polymerases are involved in the mutagenic bypass of these lesions. Successful completion of these aims will establish a critical link between UV exposure and melanomagenesis as mutation of CA and AC dinucleotides are common diver mutations in the BRAF proto-oncogene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a burden on our healthcare system due to the lack of an efficient therapy. We will define how methionine metabolism is regulated by peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ in hepatocytes to promote NAFLD. Our results will help to develop therapeutic approaches that improve the use of existing drugs to reverse efficiently this disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project involves the collection of data related to connections between regions of the brain important for maintaining standing balance in elderly fall-risk individuals. Falls are the leading cause of accidental death in older adults, and the goal of this work is to characterize important circuit interactions that may underlie fall risk by investigating the roles of motor and cognitive neural circuits that contribute to balance control. In the future, this work will help identify potential biomarkers and targets for more individualized rehabilitation therapies to improve balance function and quality of life in older individuals at risk for falls.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heroin abuse and addiction has become an epidemic health challenge, yet there continues to be a poor understanding of the molecular events that lead to the “addicted brain.” This application explores the contribution of the actin regulator drebrin in mediating behavioral, cellular, and morphological plasticity following heroin taking. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that may identify novel pharmacotherapies to combat opioid addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Ionizing radiation is one of the most common treatments used against cancer; however, radioresistance is still a signific clinical problem since cancer cells can survive and regenerate tumors. This proposal aims to understand how cells survive after exposure to radiation to enhance radiotherapy. I aim to understand how cells survive after activating apoptotic caspases, enzymes canonically known as markers of apoptosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A protein is a gene-encoded string of amino acids that folds into a three-dimensional structure. Proteins perform the molecular functions that are necessary for life, including catalysis of biochemical reactions (by enzymes), neutralization of foreign toxins (by antibodies), and stimulation of cellular activity (by hormones). The goal of this project is to develop chemical means to manipulate proteins with a precision that is unobtainable with other (e.g., genetic) methods and to endow proteins thereby with desirable attributes that could be transformative to many aspects of biomedicine.

PHR: Type 2 diabetes is the major health problem for US veterans that imposes significant physical, financial, and emotional tolls. The prevalence of Type 2 diabetes is increasing and affects over 20% of veterans, a rate significantly higher than in general civilian population. Strong association of depression with Type 2 diabetes adds to challenges for veterans who suffer from high prevalence of post-traumatic stress disorder. Thus, there is a strong and urgent need for an effective and widely applicable therapy. Excessive accumulation of lipids in beta cells is considered to contribute to the development of Type 2 diabetes. However, it still remains elusive how lipid accumulation and mobilization is regulated in beta cells. The proposal aims to increase our understanding of the regulation of lipid mobilization, a process being impaired in human islets affected by type 2 diabetes. The completion of the proposal holds potential to identify a new target that will preserve beta cell health under overnutrition and improve a treatment of type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Touch is crucial for detecting pain and pleasure alike, and different neuronal subtypes of the somatosensory dorsal root ganglia relay different qualities of touch into the central nervous system. My research will characterize the gene expression programs that orchestrate the development of these different types of sensory neurons and the role that sensory activity plays in establishing these programs and wiring the corresponding neural circuits. This work will provide insight into the developmental genetic programs that regulate sensory neuron growth, function, and, in many cases, recovery after injury.

PHR: Synaptic dysfunction serves as a key cellular substrate for the pathogenesis of multiple neuropsychiatric disorders, including autism spectrum disorders and schizophrenia. However, the molecular basis of such synaptic malfunctioning is not understood in these disorders. This proposal will use cutting-edge methodologies in stem cell and neuroscience to explore the molecular and cellular mechanisms of synaptic dysfunction in schizophrenia, which are fundamental to our understanding of disease pathogenesis and identification of novel therapeutic treatments.

PHR: This study will characterize trends in incidence of HIV, HCV and OD associated with binational drug markets and drug tourism (DT) between San Diego (SD) and Tijuana (TJ), Mexico. We will incorporate longitudinal data on binational retail drug markets and HIV and HCV sequencing data into dynamic mathematical models to forecast future HIV, HCV and OD incidence trends. This study addresses both the NIDA’s HEAL initiative and the Trans-NIH plan of the OAR, by conducting time-sensitive research to inform implementation of timely interventions to reduce incidence of HIV, HCV and OD.

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Women's health and mental health are research priority areas for VA. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is prevalent among women Veterans, but many do not engage in evidence-based psychotherapies for PTSD (i.e., PTSD treatment). Insomnia is a risk factor for PTSD development and severity. Healthy sleep is associated with improved mood, daytime functioning, and increased emotion regulation, all of which may increase PTSD treatment engagement and improve treatment outcomes. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I; first-line treatment for insomnia) may reduce treatment barriers and offer a novel, brief, and evidence-based approach to increase PTSD treatment engagement in women Veterans. We will pilot test the effect of trauma-informed CBT-I on PTSD treatment readiness and engagement among women Veterans within insomnia and PTSD and conduct qualitative interviews with pilot trial completers and non-completers to better understand the facilitators of and barriers to PTSD treatment engagement among women Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Class switch recombination and somatic hypermutation is essential for B cell-mediated immunity as its failure leads to immunodeficiency syndromes in humans. On the other hand, aberrant class switch recombination and somatic hypermutation is directly responsible for the ontogeny of mature B cell lymphomas, the most common lymphoma in humans. The goal of this application is to understand the mechanisms that promote genomic alterations in B cells to promote immunity while simultaneously preventing collateral damage. The proposal is therefore directly related to both human immunodeficiencies and B cell oncogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Nanocarriers provide delivery of cargo mRNA to liver, enabling the therapeutic and prophylactic use of this powerful biological agent. However, delivery to other organs remains a major unmet challenge. We propose to achieve this goal by conjugating to RNA nanocarriers molecules with specific affinity to markers typical of distinct types of endothelial cells lining blood vessels. Our preliminary results indicate that using antibodies to such markers enables highly effective and selective delivery and effect of RNA nanoparticles in the lungs, spleen, and brain. We will comprehensively characterize the targeting, its mechanisms and potential medical utility, and translate the best formulation(s) into the clinically useful format.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis and spinal degeneration are among the most prevalent diseases leading the acceleration of normal aging, mobility decline, and frailty. Aberrant remodeling of subchondral bone in joints and porosity in vertebral endplates may play a central role in decline of mobility and in frailty. In the proposed studies, a team of scientists at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine from different disciplines and with complementary expertise will work together to address the critical questions in skeletal joint degeneration which leads to accelerated aging and frailty that will provide foundational mechanistic insights for potential therapeutic treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative Chronic infection with the indolent bacterium Helicobacter pylori is the number one risk factor for developing gastric cancer. This project is designed to investigate underappreciated cell-specific, anti-inflammatory role of the IL-17 receptor signaling in control of inflammation and carcinogenesis. It is expected that data garnered will help identify people who are at greater risk of developing gastric cancer; ultimately leading to the development of tools that will be leveraged in either biomarker development or as supplemental immunotherapies in H. pylori infected people.

PHR: The veteran population develops chronic kidney disease (CKD) at a higher rate than the general population. Patients with CKD are at an increased risk of fracture and if a fracture occurs, patients with CKD have a greater risk of death compared to other populations. Unfortunately, treatments aimed at reducing fracture risk in CKD patients are limited in part due to the lack of extensive studies. The goal of this project is to understand a key component of the CKD-induced bone fragility – cortical porosity. Specifically, we propose experiments that will help determine the mechanisms underlying porosity infilling and how this, combined with maximizing the material properties of bone tissue, can increase bone mechanical properties. The results of these studies will provide a basis for improving the quality of life of veterans suffering from CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a deadly condition that leads to difficulty breathing and low oxygen levels in the blood. Patients with ARDS are treated with mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit, but this treatment can cause further lung injury. The purpose of this research is to understand the molecular mechanisms that cause lung injury during mechanical ventilation in order to develop new treatments for patients with ARDS.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Although underrepresented minorities continue to join STEM disciplines, examination of professorial ranks indicates there is a significant leak retaining underrepresented minorities in the biomedical science workforce. Many explanations have been proposed for this leaky pipeline such as poor mentoring, lack of community and a deficiency in research-related skills. We propose a novel summer undergraduate training program to help bridge these gaps, thereby significantly increasing the retention of these talented students in the biomedical sciences.

PHR: Project Narrative It is critical to better understand genetic causes of human neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism, intellectual disability, and schizophrenia and to use animal models of such causes to identify potential treatments. This 5-year R01 proposal capitalizes on significant progress in creating and characterizing two novel animal models of neurodevelopmental disorders that will allow us to rapidly advance this field. Extensive characterization of these new models will allow for a complete understanding of how genetic mutations in these genes alter brain function and behavior, allowing for future studies aimed at correcting altered brain function in the hope of treating behavioral symptoms in both the models and in patients.
