IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because health disparities have been identified across the spectrum of care and conditions for the hospitalized child; although responses to address disparities in pediatric care need to be multi-factorial, key strategies include fostering a more diverse pediatric workforce and developing expertise in health equity research. The project is relevant to NICHD’S R25 mission because Health Equity Academic Research in Pediatric Hospital Medicine (HEAR-PHM) is a research education program that supports creative education activities to focus on research skill development in an area of critical need, specifically health equity research focused on the acute care continuum for children. As a young pediatric subspeciality with care expertise across a broad spectrum of hospital care, PHM has the unique opportunity to promote a diverse academic workforce and develop research leaders to improve health equity in the care of hospitalized children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This training program provides state-of-the-art research training for PhD, MD, VMD, and MD/PhD postdoctoral fellows in sleep and circadian research. The program is built on a combination of relevant didactic training with individualized mentored research training. The program includes specific tracks for basic research, clinical/translational research, and development of personalized medicine.

PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE The proposed R25 program will train frontline cancer clinicians (physicians, advanced practice providers, psychologists, psychiatrists, nurses, and social workers) in the best-practice implementation of technology in cancer supportive care. Training will be carried out through pre-workshop webinars (pre-recorded); skills- based, in-person workshops focused on integration of evidence-based digital health and telehealth solutions with clinical practice, using established care approaches for cancer-related fatigue, insomnia, pain, depression and anxiety, which will also include emphasis on digital equity and working with diverse populations; and post- workshop online video and chat support from program faculty and a learning community of peers. Program content will be updated annually with expert input from our advisory board, and formative and summative evaluations annually and at the end of the program will assess trainee knowledge gained, confidence in technology use, and overall satisfaction with the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infectious diseases are a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with threats from both old and emerging pathogens. This Training Program proposes to train scientists (graduate students and post-doctoral fellows) to work at the intersection of immunology and microbiology in the study of infectious diseases. Understanding the contribution of both fields to infectious diseases will result in well-trained scientists who will discover cures and prevention strategies to reduce the global burden of infections.

PROJECT_TITLE: Immunology of Infections Disease Renewal 2023

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The NIH-funded aquatic model stock centers have expressed growing needs for them and their associated research communities to use germplasm repositories in preservation and sharing of genetic resources. Because of a lack of comprehensive repository capabilities, the National Xenopus Resource (NXR), Ambystoma Genetic Resource Center (AGSC), and National Resource for Aplysia (NRA) face many challenges including the risk of losing valuable genetic lines, inefficiency of maintaining living animals, and the struggle to meet increasing demands from their research communities. Based on the success of the ongoing Hub R24 that has developed basic cryopreservation protocols and customized these based on the specific resources and needs of the stock centers, we propose to advance the capabilities at the resource centers from feasibility establishment to operational repositories with high-throughput production and routine quality management programs, and to advance the Aquatic Germplasm and Genetic Resources Center (AGGRC) Hub and NIH Aquatic Biomedical Germplasm Repository Network to facilitate resource management, sharing, and distribution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: C8. Project Narrative The field of protein biotechnology continues to address widely recognized ongoing and emerging public health challenges through medical advances, but contributions extend further to broader public health challenges such as food insecurity, sustainable agriculture, and mitigation of global climate change. To capture this holistic contribution and to train a workforce of skilled and well-trained scientists, our PhD training program focuses on transdisciplinary protein biotechnology that encompasses contributions from fields ranging from engineering, chemistry, chemical engineering, microbiology, molecular biology, and molecular plant sciences. Our trainee-centered, project-based learning approach equips trainees with skills and experiences applicable to a wide range of biotechnology careers in private, public, and academic settings.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biotechnology;Protein Chemistry;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Biotechnology: Emphasis in Protein Chemistry
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - B[TWD-B]

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advances in human genomics are transforming the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. However, there are too few clinical geneticists and counselors to meet rising demand and non-geneticist clinicians feel under-prepared to incorporate genetics into their medical practice, highlighting the need to produce more genomically-literate clinicians. To help meet this need, we plan to develop an innovative one-year Master of Science (MS) program in Genomic Medicine for UCSF medical students.

PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed training program, “BUilding an InterprofessionaL and Diverse workforce in substance Use and Pain” (BUILD-UP), will train the next generation of researchers at the intersection of substance use and chronic pain, a cutting-edge field with few current training options. BUILD-UP will prioritize recruitment of postdoctoral fellows from diverse groups including individuals who identify as being from a group excluded based on ethnicity and race, being from a disadvantaged background, having a disability, or being LGBT+, and will reduce barriers and promote equity in participation by allowing fully remote training. Therefore, BUILD- UP will have the important public health impact of both expanding and diversifying the workforce in this critical area.

PROJECT_TITLE: Building an interprofessional and diverse workforce in substance use and pain

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this research training program is to train outstanding academic physician-scientists in Neurological Surgery and Neurology. The program combines longitudinal interdisciplinary neuroscience instruction with strong faculty mentorship throughout their residency, and a structured resident research experience. Participants will complete the program with the necessary skills and experience to design and perform high- quality collaborative neuroscience research, acquire independent funding, and attain academic faculty physician-scientists appointments.

PHR: Project Narrative Research in hemostasis, thrombosis, and vascular biology addresses fundamental mechanisms underlying bleeding, thrombotic disorders, and diseases of the blood vessels. Taken together, these pathologies account for more than half of all morbidity and mortality among U.S. citizens. This Program in Blood Coagulation and Vascular Biology will train the next generation of scientists to study problems related to hemostasis, thrombosis, and vascular biology.

PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL Stem cells, which are present in most tissues, are responsible for maintaining tissue structure and function during normal activity and for repairing tissues in response to injury. One of the hallmarks of aging is the decline in the ability of tissues to perform these functions due at least in part to the decline in stem cell function with age. The studies of this proposal are designed to examine why stem cell function declines with age and how to restore youthful function to aged stem cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Sleep disturbance is a prominent concern among gynecologic cancer survivors with severe and negative implications for health-related quality of life (HRQOL); however, leading non-pharmacologic sleep interventions often do not maximally benefit this population, possibly due to high treatment burden. The proposed study will identify barriers and facilitators of treatment adherence, and optimize a behavioral intervention to diminish sleep disturbance, increase HRQOL, and reduce symptom burden among gynecologic cancer survivors. This study will yield an improved treatment package to address the prevalent and impactful concern of sleep disturbance among gynecologic cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Worldwide there are estimated to be 2.9 million cholera cases annually and 95,000 deaths in cholera-endemic countries. The risk for cholera is 30 times higher for individuals living in close proximity to cholera patients during one week period after the index patient seeks care at a health facility. Given these findings, effective targeted water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) interventions are urgently needed to reduce cholera for this high risk population; this study will design, implement, and evaluate a scalable, theory and evidence based ring WASH intervention to reduce cholera infections and increase sustained WASH behaviors in transmission hotspots around cholera cases in Bangladesh.

PHR: Project Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Annually around the world, millions of old (and even young) people cared for in Intensive Care Units (ICUs) suffer through a period of confusion or delirium. These ICU survivors have new life-altering, long-lasting, and often permanent cognitive impairment, which looks like Alzheimer’s disease and/or related dementias. This BRAIN-ICU-2 Study [Bringing to light the Risk factors And Incidence of Neuropsychological dysfunction (dementia) in ICU Survivors, 2nd Study] will define the relationship between ICU delirium and dementia, will explain this unfortunate and life-changing brain damage in ICU survivors, and will pave the way for preventive programs, strategic rehabilitation, and targeted future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will result in the development of a serological test for accurate detection of Chagas infection. Existing Chagas serological tests are prone to inconclusive or false- negative test results, which can lead to increased disease transmission and life-threatening illness due to misdiagnosis. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIAID’s mission by advancing neglected tropical disease research through the development of new diagnostics to improve the diagnosis of individuals with Chagas disease, which will ultimately improve patient outcomes.

PHR: Hypertension afflicts more than 30% of the adult population and is one of the most common causes of progressive chronic kidney disease (CKD) in the US. There is a disproportionate increased prevalence of CKD in veterans compared with the general population and nearly half have hypertension. The percentage of hypertensive patients who ultimately develop ESKD has remained constant despite treatment. The present application proposes to fill gaps in understanding how the microvasculature of the kidney is predisposed to hypertension-induced changes that lead to detrimental arteriolar remodeling, accompanying glomerular injury, and development of progressive CKD.

PHR: Narrative Statement To date, few clinical trials for tauopathy have specifically targeted pathological tau, yet neurofibrillary tangles are the diagnostic neuropathological hallmark of AD that is most closely associated with cognitive decline. To help fill this gap, we propose to develop novel neuroprotective strategies that target pathological tau in AD and related dementias. Specifically, we propose to develop biological lead molecules antagonizing MSUT2 binding to RNA. These novel tool agents will provide a proof-of- concept demonstration that inhibiting MSUT2 can reverse pathological tau deposition, and they will support mechanistic investigation of MSUT2 as a critical modulator of pathological tau.

ORG_NAME: JAMES H QUILLEN VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PTSD has a greater incidence rate in Veterans compared to the general population. Furthermore, Veterans with PTSD are almost twice as likely to develop issues with alcohol abuse and alcohol use disorder (AUD). Recent evidence indicates that the brain areas associated with PTSD and drug addiction have many common characteristics. As a result, there is evidence that PTSD symptoms contribute to the development of alcoholism, and alcohol interferes with the treatment of PTSD. Unfortunately, the treatments that are currently being used to treat individuals with PTSD and AUD are not effective. Thus, there is a great need to better understand how the brain is changed in this disorder. In doing so, we can develop new treatment drugs that can help these individuals manage their symptoms and lead a normal life despite having experienced a traumatic event.

PHR: Narrative: Immunotherapy is changing cancer care. There is tremendous hope that it will cure cancer in Veterans even when the cancer has spread or metastasized. Unfortunately, most Veterans do not respond to immunotherapy. Therefore, we aim to design more effective treatments by combining radiotherapy, and immunotherapy. These therapies interact in the tumor because of tumor cell death. The immune system reacts differently to dead cells based on how they died, which makes it important to understand how best to kill a tumor cell. With this information, we hope to make immunotherapy work better and improve the lives of Veterans with cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The molecular mechanisms underlying the pathogenic nature of APOE4 in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) are not fully elucidated. In previous funding period, we have uncovered a novel regulatory mechanism of miR-195 targeted at APOE4-associated cognitive deficits and lysosomal defects in AD. Our preliminary results further support the role of miR-195 as an anti-inflammatory miRNA in regulating microglial function. Therefore, we will characterize in this renewal application, the regulation of microglial function in AD by miR-195 with in vivo studies of humanized APOE mouse models, ex vivo microglial culture and 3-D co-culture system, and validation studies of human brain samples. The scRNA-seq data from mouse brains and RNA-seq/miRNA-seq data from mouse microglial and 3-D co-culture will be integrated to perform high resolution multiscale network modeling and to elucidate novel molecular signatures driven by miR-195 protective against APOE4-induced neuro-inflammation.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and alcohol use disorder (AUD) are common problems among U.S. Veterans. People with PTSD are more likely to develop AUD, and it is often harder to treat someone with both PTSD and AUD than with either illness alone. In fact, people with both PTSD and AUD generally have more severe symptoms and higher risk of suicide. Current treatments for PTSD and AUD are not helpful for many people, and more work is needed to find the causes of these illnesses, especially those that contribute to both. In our proposal, we will build upon the tremendous strides in understanding the genetic causes of these illnesses to identify novel treatment targets for them. Furthermore, by studying both conditions at the same time we are more likely to identify common contributors to both illnesses that could be used to tailor treatment for each illness alone and both illnesses when they occur together.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis is the most commonly used drug among people who drink alcohol, and conflicting evidence suggests that cannabinoids (the chemical constituents of the cannabis plant, including delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol [THC]) may confer both harms and benefits on the symptoms of alcohol use disorder (AUD). Animal studies suggest the effects of cannabis among heavy drinkers may be partially due to the impact of THC on the microbiota-gut-brain axis (MGBA; which refers to the bidirectional communication between the digestive, immune, and central nervous systems), however no human studies have explicitly explored this question. This observational study will inform our understanding of the risks and potential harm-reduction benefits of cannabis among heavy drinkers by investigating the effects of THC in legal-market cannabis on acute and daily alcohol consumption, AUD symptoms, and MGBA function among heavy drinking, regular cannabis users.

PHR: Project Narrative Children with Down syndrome (DS), irrespective of having other risk factors, are at increased risk for respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection. Whether children with DS benefit from RSV immunoprophylaxis, the only currently available preventive therapy for RSV, is not known. This study, the largest study ever conducted, is adequately powered and aims to determine the short- and long-term effectiveness of RSV immunoprophylaxis in children with DS; it will provide necessary information regarding effectiveness of RSV immunoprophylaxis that will impact policy and potentially improve health in children with DS.

PHR: S. pneumoniae is the leading cause of community acquired pneumonia, the most common infectious cause of death among the veteran population. Despite a rigorous pneumococcal vaccination program, S. pneumoniae remains a major health threat to veterans. The severity of pneumococcal infection depends on the interaction between bacterial and host factors. S. pneumoniae infection induces oxidative stress in the host and leads to epithelial dysfunction, tissue injury and a dysregulated inflammatory response. Preliminary research included in this grant suggests that oxidative mitochondrial DNA damage may play a role in mediating the pathogenicity of pneumococcal infection. This project proposes to investigate the bacterial and host factors that mediate mitochondrial DNA damage and repair. These translational studies will determine if therapies targeting enhancement of mitochondrial DNA repair can improve the host response to pneumococcal infection, thereby leading to clinical trials of this novel therapeutic strategy in veterans suffering from pneumococcal infection.

ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Salt sensitive hypertension, a subset of essential hypertension, affects more than 15% of the adult U.S. population. Epidemiologic evidence suggests salt sensitive hypertension has a worse cardiovascular prognosis than salt resistant hypertension, but the mechanism underlying the poor prognosis is unknown. This difference in clinical outcome imply differences in the pathophysiology of hypertension. Investigations have suggested that elevated tissue cholesterol may contribute to activated Na transport in the kidney and reduced release of natriuretic molecules, raising systemic blood pressure. Tissue cholesterol also stimulates inflammation which may explain the excess mortality observed with sodium sensitivity. In this research application, we develop a novel mouse model where ABCA1, a tissue cholesterol efflux protein, is ablated from sodium transporting tubular cells to determine whether high cholesterol content in tubular cells leads to salt sensitive hypertension, inflammation and apoptosis.

PHR: Venous thrombus embolism (VTE) which includes deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is a common and serious clinical problem. Despite standard anticoagulant therapy, 25%-50% of patients with clots in the deep veins of the arms and legs progress to chronic post-clot problems resulting in significant disability, loss of productivity, and healthcare costs. DVT and its complications have increased in the Veteran population over the last decade. A recent study of almost 500,000 surgeries performed at the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Centers found that over half of the surgical patients developed VTE after surgery within 90 days. Patients who display faster thrombus resolution have a lower risk of complications and better prognosis than those patients whose thrombus resolves much slower. The goal of this research is to better understand the inflammatory processes that regulate venous thrombus resolution, and to develop specific therapies to accelerate the resolution process for clinical management of DVT.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Involvement with the criminal justice system, substance use, and infection with HIV and hepatitis C virus are syndemic in the United States. Despite this public health crisis, there is a relative dearth of clinical research aimed at improving treatment outcomes among CJ populations. To address this gap and increase the number and capacity of clinical scientists working with criminal justice-involved populations, we have established this clinical research training program based at the Providence-Boston Center for AIDS Research (CFAR) and in collaboration with the Brown University and Boston University Schools of Public Health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to generate a new strategy to stop development of Plasmodium falciparum in the Anopheles gambiae mosquito, the most important malaria vector. In this strategy Plasmodium parasites are killed with antimalarial drugs during their development in the mosquito by exposing female Anopheles to drug-treated surfaces such as mosquito nets. These studies will provide new effective tools to aid future malaria elimination efforts.

PHR: Project Narrative Dementia is a long term, incurable condition characterized by progressive loss in cognition and function, with many patients receiving intensive medical interventions within the last year of life, despite it being unclear if these intensive measures of care actually benefit the patients’ quality of life or survival. Advance Care Planning (ACP) provides patients and their caregivers the opportunity to discuss their goals, values, and priorities for healthcare – particularly in the context of end-of-life care. This Mentored Career Development Award (K23) will launch my independent investigator career devoted to advance effective ways to improve ACP among community-dwelling cognitively impaired older adults.

PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this translational research project is to develop a new targeted cancer immunotherapy using a biocompatible and bioactive nanoparticle drug delivery system for the treatment of cancer patients with comorbid atherosclerosis or at a high risk of developing atherosclerosis. The proposed research project aims to develop a multifunctional immunomodulatory nanoparticle with the ability of targeted delivery into tumors and atherosclerotic plaques, inhibition of tumor cell growth, activation of anti-tumor immune responses and cytotoxic T cell function, and reduction of cholesterol-rich macrophages and effector T cells in atherosclerotic plaques. The effects of the targeted nanoparticle/drug on the inhibition of progression of metastatic colon cancer and atherosclerosis and the improvement of overall survival will be evaluated in mouse colon tumor models, dual mouse colon and atherosclerosis models, and human colon cancer patient derived xenograft models for feasibility of future clinical translation.

PHR: Project Narrative:  Sleep is essential for healthy brain function, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease are associated with disrupted sleep. This project will use new imaging approaches to identify how neural activity, blood flow, and cerebrospinal fluid flow are jointly regulated in the brain during sleep and wakefulness. We will identify how sleep-dependent brain physiology changes in healthy aging and in individuals with genetic risk for Alzheimer’s disease, to advance our understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying the link between sleep and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Deeply conserved human genes are strongly linked to diverse diseases, from cancer to neurodegeneration to cardiovascular disease. We propose to study these critical human genes by (1) using a comparative proteomics approach to biochemically define how the encoded proteins physically organize into multiprotein assemblies, which will help us better understand a variety of human genetic diseases, (2) systematically replacing yeast genes with their human equivalents, using the humanized yeast to directly experimentally measure the effects of human genetic variation and gene-drug interactions, and (3) advancing new proteomics technologies that would have broad applications across biology and medicine. Success of these efforts will provide new insights into basic human cell biology and biochemistry, laying the foundation for future attempts to intervene, chemically or genetically, with proteins critical to human cell health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Allergies are a major cause of illness in the US. Currently, there are no cures for allergies and the available therapies involve non-specific suppression of the immune system. The goal of this project is to establish a detailed understanding of IgE/allergen interactions in mast cell degranulation, and to engineer allergen specific molecules to inhibit allergic responses without non-specific suppression of the immune system.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: One of the basic goals of doing research in health care is to make health better. This is done by moving the best research out of the lab, and bringing it to doctors so they can make care less expensive, more effective, or both. We generally call this process translational research, and years of experience has shown it can be very difficult. Fortunately, experts in translational research can teach the necessary skills so researchers can try to solve the many translational research problems earlier and faster. The VA-TEAM Center brings a team of experts, a series of online workshops, and a focused mentoring plan to the VA so we can change how the VA research community approaches the problems of translational research.

PHR: Alcohol is the 3rd leading cause of preventable death in the US, and binge drinking has an economic burden of $186 billion/year. Binge drinking is highly prevalent in active military duty personnel and veterans. More than 40% of military veterans have a lifetime history of alcohol use disorder (AUD). Thus, alcohol misuse exerts a large burden, especially within the VA. How individuals respond to their first experiences with alcohol is related to their risk for developing an AUD, including frequent early adult binge drinking (King et al., 2011; McCarty et al., 2004). Understanding the brain circuitry that underlies this dangerous pattern of drinking is an important first step in learning about vulnerability factors for AUD. We propose to identify brain regions engaged during binge drinking and manipulate specific brain circuits to determine what role they play in binge drinking. We will learn which circuits are engaged early, and this informs us of mechanisms that are involved in risk for AUD. If we can block them, then we are interfering with a mechanism important for risk for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Purinergic signaling is a type of cell-to-cell communication that occurs in all organs. Extracellular ATP and ADP are important purinergic signals, but we lack methods to accurately measure them in biological samples. We are developing sensors to address this need, and they will be used to understand everything from brain function to our immune responses and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We have developed a high-throughput biodosimetry device, the FAST-DOSE (Fluorescent Automated Screening Tool for Dosimetry) assay system to measure radiation-responsive proteins in human blood leukocytes for retrospective estimation of radiation dose. Studies are designed to validate and test the performance of the blood protein biomarker panel to accurately predict absorbed dose after ionizing radiation exposure. We will correlate biomarker expression levels and time kinetics with hematopoietic injury, based on peripheral blood leukocyte counts and bone marrow toxicity in humanized mice.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postpartum depression is common, undertreated, and has far reaching consequences for both mother and child; thus, novel, in-home treatments that remove barriers to care and target modifiable underpinnings are urgently needed. This study will test the efficacy of wearable bright light therapy for postpartum depression and determine how changes in sleep and circadian timing influence treatment response. Findings from the study will inform treatment targets to reduce the major burden of postpartum depression, with long-term benefits for women and their offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory disfunction has been identified as a key symptom in the clinical profile of patients with pathogenic variants of the potassium channel KCNQ2. The role of KCNQ2 channels in respiratory homeostasis remains unexplored. The proposed research will identify the roles of KCNQ2 channels as well as KCNQ2 pathogenic variants in respiratory homeostasis, thus providing an integrated model of the respiratory circuit in the context of KCNQ2 function, which will serve as a foundation for potential therapeutic targets in respiratory disease which include but are not limited to KCNQ2 encephalopathy. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The EGF receptor is mutated or over-expressed in a variety of human tumors. Different tumors express structurally different forms of the EGFR as well as different ligands. To fully understand how the EGFR signals growth, it is necessary to understand how the different parts of the EGFR contribute to the biochemical changes that it induces in cells and how the different ligands can modify that biochemistry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The secretory pathway plays a central role in processing and sorting cellular proteins, but there are major gaps in our understanding of how this pathway is organized and how it operates. By using budding yeasts and cultured mammalian cells, we aim to elucidate conserved core principles of secretory pathway function. This knowledge will illuminate key aspects of cell biology while providing improved tools for basic and translational biomedical research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is the leading cause of infertility in the USA and around the world, with hyperandrogenic forms of PCOS conservatively affecting 8-10% of women, and all forms of PCOS affecting up to 25%. The proposed research investigates the origins and mechanisms underlying how the typical regulation of reproduction by the brain in prenatally androgenized mice, which exhibit several symptoms that resemble PCOS. The goals are to produce new knowledge of the changes in the brain in this model, studies that cannot be done in humans, and to identify new therapeutic approaches to treat both infertility and other aspects of this disorder.

PHR: Women are the fastest growing subgroup of U.S. Veterans. There is a notably high incidence of breast cancer among younger military women (20% to 40% higher). The incident rate of breast cancer for active duty women is seven times higher than the average incident rate of fifteen other cancer types across all service members. Thus, there is an urgent unmet need to effectively diagnose, manage and cure breast cancer in the veteran population. Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is prevalent among young women veterans, and shows a tendency to rapidly metastasize. Despite a short favorable management with chemotherapy, patients with metastatic disease have a median overall survival of about 18 months. While Wnt/β-catenin signaling has been one of the major factors driving TNBC metastases, therapeutic strategies are still evolving. Our research efforts will advance this field and unravel critical information that identifies novel drug targets. Our efforts are congruent with the mission of the VA women's health initiative.

ORG_NAME: SOUTHERN ARIZONA VA HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) remains an enormous public health concern, as no effective therapies have proven useful after renal injury has occurred. Mitochondrial biogenesis, the process of replacing dysfunctional mitochondria with new mitochondria, represents a novel approach to stimulate cell and organ repair/regeneration after renal injury, and accelerate the return of renal function. We will study the mechanisms and efficacy by which serotonin receptor signaling induces mitochondrial biogenesis and vascular and renal recovery in AKI. This novel approach may not only lead to new therapeutic approaches to treat AKI injury but also other acute organ failures (e.g. VETERAN traumatic brain injury, stroke, and myocardial infarction), chronic organ failures (e.g. VETERAN post-traumatic stress disorder, metabolic syndrome, neurodegenerative diseases) and mitochondrial diseases.

PHR: As with the overall national population, colorectal cancer remains the second leading cause of cancer death in the US veteran population. During the last 40 years, the proportion of colorectal cancer has increased by about 15% in the veteran population and thus constitutes a significant health risk for all veterans and their family members including women especially over 50 years of age. The aberrant regulation of tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes plays a pivotal role in the transformation of normal epithelium into carcinoma in situ and metastatic cancer. STRAP, a cellular protein, is upregulated in colon cancer, promotes cell proliferation, tumorigenicity, metastasis, cancer stem-like cell (CSC) self-renewal, and drug resistance, thus contributing to worse survival of patients with chemotherapy. This study will discover novel and less toxic nanoparticles targeting STRAP, which will be used to codeliver 5-FU and Oxaliplatin. The proposed research is very crucial for the development of successful therapeutic strategies for colon cancer.

PHR: Approximately 60% of adult epilepsy cases are due to Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (TLE). TLE is the most frequent  type of post- traumatic epilepsy, causing significant morbidity in the veteran population. It is often drug- resistant  requiring surgery. Even after surgery, 20- 30% of patients continue to have ictal events. TLE seizures entrain  cortical networks, causing cognitive deficits that include executive, memory, and neuropsychiatric dysfunction.  After initiation by a precipitating event, a seizure- free “epileptogenic” period typically follows before TL epilepsy  sets in. How cortical and hippocampal circuits get modified during this epileptogenic period remains unknown.  Here, we combine state- of- the art 2- photon imaging and optogenetic techniques to study how hyperexcitability  emerges in neocortical circuits during epileptogenesis in the pilocarpine model of TLE, and to identify possible  ways to reverse it by modulating the activity of specific cell types. Information obtained will be critical for  identifying cell- specific targets for intervention to prevent epileptogenesis and its cognitive sequelae in TLE.

PHR: Prostate cancer (PCa) is one of the major health issues for the aging Veterans population warranting investigations to further advance knowledge of the disease pathobiology to benefit PCa patients, which accords with the VA Healthcare mission. Resistance to current androgen pathway-targeting drugs is a major aspect of PCa progression from castration-sensitive to the fatal castration-resistant PCa (CRPC). Increased expression levels of tumor-addictive pro-survival protein kinase CK2 (formerly casein kinase II or 2) correlate with advanced PCa. We have discovered an exciting aspect of crosstalk between this kinase and androgenic pathway targeting in PCa. The proposed investigation of the mechanism of protein kinase CK2 interaction with this pathway and ensuing changes in nuclear proteomic landscape will yield novel knowledge that has the potential of being rapidly translated to the clinic for therapy in PCa patients.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: The major microvascular complications of diabetes include diabetic retinopathy, diabetic kidney disease and diabetic peripheral neuropathy, each of which can significantly reduce quality of life and increase mortality by causing blindness, end-stage renal disease and lower-limb amputation, respectively. Because nearly 25% of veterans are affected by diabetes, it is important to identify ways to prevent these complications. The goals of this proposal are to (1) determine whether systemic reduction of the facilitative glucose transporter, Glut1, prevents these complications, (2) to determine whether the addition of Glut1 reduction to the current standard of care for Type 2 diabetes augments protection against each complication and (3) to elucidate mechanisms that regulate Glut1 in each tissue.

ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Obesity, a chronic disease in Veterans, promotes comorbidities such as cardiovascular diseases, metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Obese subjects with COVID19 have 33% fatality rate. 61-83% of Veterans and DoD beneficiaries are overweight or obese, a significantly higher percent compared to civilians. The healthcare costs of obesity and its related diseases exceeds $1.7 billion annually for the VA. Of note is that even though women veterans are only 10% of the total veteran population, 44% women veterans are obese. Furthermore, a startling 75% of Iraq and Afghanistan veterans are overweight or obese and approximately 30% of Gulf War and Gulf Era veterans are morbidly obese (BMI>40) (VA/DoD statistics). As part of personalized, proactive Veteran‐driven care, treatment of obesity is consistent with the priorities outlined by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA/DoD Clinical Guidelines, 2014).

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Project Narrative In the US, an estimated 39.6 million people (~13%), including 8.5 million Veterans are 65 or older and at risk for developing chronic sleep disturbance, a frequent and challenging problem of aging. Fragmented and poor sleep is associated with adverse health outcomes, including increased risk of fall, anxiety, depressive disorders, cognitive decline, and Alzheimer's disease. Also, aging Veterans have a high prevalence of medical and psychiatric disorders that can further aggravate sleep disruption. This research program will use cutting edge approaches to determine if disruption of hypothalamic neurogenesis causes the dysfunction of critical sleep-regulatory systems and consequent sleep disturbance in aging; and if sleep disruption in aging could be mitigated by improving hypothalamic neurogenesis and anti-inflammatory measures. These preclinical studies may help develop novel therapeutic options for optimizing sleep health in elderly Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Pathophysiologic disturbances in phosphate homeostasis involving the hormone FGF23, and its co-receptor Klotho, such as those in rare Mendelian disorders autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets (ADHR) and hyperphosphatemic familial tumoral calcinosis (hfTC), or common disorders such as chronic kidney disease (CKD), lead to severe mineral disease. These disorders currently have inadequate treatments. We expect that our proposed studies will reveal new mechanisms involved in phosphate homeostasis, providing novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, alcohol causes 3.3 million deaths and is a leading risk factor for injury among young adults. Currently in low-resource settings like Tanzania, alcohol-related treatment and resources are scarce while the use of alcohol and the harms caused by alcohol are growing exponentially. This proposal evaluates a Brief Intervention for alcohol for patients suffering an alcohol-related injury who present for care to the Emergency Department at Kilimanjaro Christian Medical Center in Moshi, Tanzania.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Program Narrative A broadly effective vaccine is needed to eradicate hepatitis C. Circulating hepatitis C virus is highly diverse genetically and a working vaccine must be able to protect against diverse viral strains. This research program will solve structures of important viral envelope proteins in order to facilitate rational design of a vaccine to focus immune responses on conserved, vulnerable sites on the virus for maximal protection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: This proposal aims to understand the mechanisms by which mutations in the O-GlcNAc Transferase (OGT) gene lead to X-Linked Intellectual Disability (XLID). Within the United States, one in 500 males are affected with XLID, which is characterized by limitations in intellectual functioning and adaptive behavior. Understanding the underlying mechanisms behind this neurodevelopmental phenotype would provide insight into the role of OGT in transcription regulation and early development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Synaptic connections are the basis of brain function, and these synapses need to be maintained throughout development and adulthood. This project will study the mechanisms that keep synaptic connections stable, by investigating how the components of the synapse are organized and regulated. Understanding how synapses are maintained will provide insight into how to protect synaptic connections in neurodegenerative diseases and during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in RNA processing and degradation enzymes (RNases) have been shown to cause human disease. Yet, there are many proteins involved in RNA degradation and processing pathways that have not been previously identified as RNases, and for some enzymes that have been identified, their targets and mechanisms of action remain obscure. This study will characterize a group of RNases to better understand the link between dysfunctional RNA processing and degradation, and the development of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dexterous movements require significant coordination of muscle groups across multiple joints, and the cerebellum is critical for ensuring that these behaviors are smooth and precise. This proposal seeks to define the contributions of an underexplored cerebellar output pathway to the spinal cord to the rapid refinement of skilled forelimb movements. By expanding our knowledge of how the cerebellum facilitates the speed and precision of forelimb behaviors, this work will provide valuable insight into the neural basis of dexterous movement, and lay the groundwork for improved diagnosis and treatment of cerebellar pathologies.

PHR: Within the Veterans Affairs healthcare system, around 25% of military veterans have diabetes. Despite innovations in both wound care and diabetes management, diabetic wounds remain the leading cause of amputation for VA patients. The loss of mobility and independence in these veterans has a significant impact on their quality of life and that of their caregivers. With this proposal, we will study stalled healing in diabetic patients by identifying correlated biomarkers. These biomarkers will be the foundation for a preclinical algorithm, enabling translation of our biomarker matrix into a clinically relevant, predictive model for wound healing. Ultimately, the long-term goal of this research will help future developments of low-cost, non-invasive treatment protocols that utilize personalized tools of assessment and can be readily implemented throughout the Veterans Affairs healthcare system.

PHR: Obesity, diabetes, and their pathological sequelae are a tremendous burden to the population in general but especially so for the Veteran population. Adipose tissue excess contributes to these health problems. This proposal addresses adipose tissue specifically with respect to adaptive thermogenesis, or ‘browning’. It is increasingly appreciated that adult humans have ‘brown fat’—highly metabolically active fat depots that metabolize lipids to generate heat. Brown adipose depots also clear glucose and triacylglycerols form circulation, secrete beneficial hormones, and contribute in other ways to overall health. Recent observations show that white fat, e.g. abdominal and subcutaneous, can transdifferentiate to a brown-like phenotype. This may be an attractive strategy to reduce body fat and improve metabolic health. We have identified new pathways that regulate the white to brown-like conversion and will determine the mechanisms by which this occurs and test whether we can manipulate this pathway in mouse models to improve overall metabolic health.

PHR: The VA patient population is characterized by a high number of patients suffering from age-related degenerative diseases including disorders of bone metabolism, obesity, and diabetes. The investigator’s recent work and that of others has demonstrated an endocrine link between bone and glucose and fatty acid metabolism. The studies proposed in this renewal application examine novel functions of the bone- derived protein sclerostin in adipose tissue physiology. This information will help clarify how the skeleton communicates with other energy consuming tissues and may explain the close association between bone disease and diabetes/obesity in humans; which should have an immediate impact on the management and treatment of these related metabolic disturbances in aging Veterans.

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Temporal lobe epilepsy is frequently caused by head trauma, including war-time head trauma and affects thousands of veterans today. Many patients with temporal lobe epilepsy have frequent seizures and do not respond to medications. Many of these patients are also not candidates for epilepsy surgery. Most of these patients also develop severe problems with their memory and mood. Therefore better treatments are needed to prevent the development of epilepsy as well as the memory and mood difficulties after head trauma. How the brain develops the tendency to have repeated seizures after head trauma is not understood. This proposal will use new miniaturized microscope and electrical recordings to understand how different cell types in the brain change their activity in the first few weeks after injury. By understanding which cells malfunction, we hope to target the activity of these cells specifically and prevent the development of epilepsy, memory problems, and depression after head injury.

ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) is one of the most common etiology of dementia in the growing elderly population including veterans. At present several risk factors of VCID have been identified and there is growing evidence that these risk factors involve elevation of ADMA, a metabolic waste of proteins causing vascular disease, in the blood. This study is designed to delineate the role and mechanism of ADMA-induced brain microvessel disease and to evaluate ADMA as a potential of drug target for VCID therapy.

ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Cardiovascular disease is a devastating disorder that has a major impact on length and quality of life. The population is aging and between the years 2020 and 2060, the number of people over the age of 65 is expected to increase by 68% in the United States. The number of heart and vascular procedures (balloon angioplasties and vascular grafts) that will be performed in 2040 is expected to be more than twice the number performed in 2008. Similar increases will occur in the Veteran population. Regardless of whether the veterans undergo endovascular management or open surgical intervention, the long-term results are limited by throm- bosis or restenosis. If endothelial cells migrate across the injured area and create an intact endothelial surface that prevents clotting and scar formation inside the blood vessels, the outcome for veterans undergoing procedures to treat heart and vascular disease will improve significantly. Improving outcomes will decrease the need for reintervention and improve veterans’ quality of life, leading to a very high reward for the project.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep is a crucial variable in neurodegenerative disease: disease progression disrupts sleep, and disrupted sleep worsens brain degeneration. This research will define cellular and molecular links between sleep and degeneration of the brain, with the ultimate goal of leveraging sleep as a modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer’s and other dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The Yale-Metropolitan Emergency Trial network to advance patient Outcomes (Yale-METRO) is comprised of a primary Hub Yale-New Haven Health System and 5 geographically proximate Spokes that are all part of integrated health systems: Hartford Health, Rhode Island/Brown University Health System; Mount Sinai Health System, New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medicine, and Montefiore Health System, with over 1.6 million ED visits combined. Covering a densely populated area of more than 8 million people throughout Connecticut, Rhode Island, Southern Massachusetts, Southeast New York and 4 boroughs of New York City, Yale-METRO provides a large diverse population for any clinical trial proposed by the SIREN network. Using innovative technological strategies this experienced team of researchers is uniquely poised to test new interventions and therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Orofacial clefts (OFCs) are characterized by a split or opening of the lip and/or palate during prenatal development and are among the most common birth defects in the world. In this project we will leverage a large diverse OFC cohort (n = 24,195) composed of 5 distinct ethnic groups to study genetic risk factors of OFC and perform novel gene discovery. In addition, we will explore the genetic influence of 3D facial variation on OFC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Emotional abuse (EA) during childhood and adolescence increases risk for depression and is particularly common among sexual minority youth (SMY; individuals with same sex romantic identities and attractions), a population disproportionately affected by depression. Adolescent depression is associated with alterations in the brain systems that process reward and self-relevant information, and those alterations could explain how EA contributes to the development of depression. The present follow-up study will examine the impact of EA on reward and self-biased processing neural systems and associated depressive systems among SMY, a high-risk population for whom there is a public health imperative to address depression disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE E-cadherin is an essential adhesion protein that mediates complex cell movement during tissue formation and wound healing; mutations in E-cadherin are characteristic of certain cancers. However, little is known about how E-cadherin structure and adhesion are regulated. This proposal will provide a detailed molecular-level understanding of how cells regulate E-cadherin adhesion and identify E-cadherin structures that are important in tissue formation, wound healing and cancer.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Stroke is a major cause of morbidity and mortality among Veterans in the United States, and results in permanent brain injury due to a lack of blood flow. I have studied the genetics of one of nature's most resilient animals, the Arctic ground squirrel, which survives extreme environmental conditions as well as dramatically reduced blood flow as a natural part of hibernation. I aim to discover precisely how adaptations in Arctic ground squirrel proteins can help brain cells survive a stroke.

ORG_NAME: CLEMENT J. ZABLOCKI VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Dysfunctional breathing is the major cause of morbidity and mortality after traumatic cervical spinal cord injury (cSCI). It often necessitates assisted ventilation, thus stressing the need to develop strategies to restore breathing. Individuals with cSCI continue to suffer from respiratory complications throughout life. As the incidence of spine trauma has been increasing in modern warfare and the incidence of progressive cervical spinal cord injury increases due to an aging veteran population, SCI will continue to provide a significant challenge to the Veterans affairs. This proposal examines a novel and clinically impactful treatment option with a particular focus on promoting respiratory plasticity of the spared respiratory neural network at a late stage after cSCI. Promoting recovery in the chronic phase is an extremely challenging task. By improving the respiratory function of military veterans who have sustained a cervical SCI, a significant number of health complications and mortality will be prevented.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to the public health because CRPC and advanced CaP, are increasingly becoming refractory and difficult to treat, represents a major national cost measured by both patient suffering and economic burden; and despite significant advances in care, clinical data suggest that refractory rates are at 30%. Upon conclusion, we will understand the role for co-delivery of chemotherapeutic agent and gene silencing agent in treatment outcomes for refractory and advanced CaP, and this discovery will stimulate the opening of a new avenue in nanoparticle based targeted therapeutics for prostate cancer.

PHR: This project seeks to improve the prevention and treatment of sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in Veterans. The impacts of hearing loss on quality of life, psychological status and employability are of profound importance to Veterans, as military service carries a high risk of SNHL. This risk increases rapidly, since the degree and nature of military noise exposure has grown. In addition, SNHL and tinnitus are high-probability consequences of blast injury. An unfortunately high percentage of military personnel returning from Middle East duty have significant SNHL, with threshold shift and/or tinnitus. There are also profound financial implications for the VA. VA rehabilitation costs for hearing loss and tinnitus are high and rising rapidly. Disability payments for hearing disorders are higher than for any other disability, with costs exceeding $2.0 billion/year and estimated to reach $3 billion/year in the near future. Hearing- related disorders are the fastest growing disability, currently affecting more than a million veterans.

PHR: This proposal will investigate the ability of a novel Neurotherapy called DRQ that is being developed by the Vandenbark laboratory to inhibit a newly implicated proinflammatory factor (TREM-1) and pathogenic T cells that can worsen clinical and histological signs of paralytic disease in a mouse model for multiple sclerosis (MS) called experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). The proposal will also evaluate the ability of DRQ to stimulate neuroprotective and regenerative pathways to help repair damaged myelinated axons during the DRQ-induced EAE recovery process. These studies will provide new insights into the pathogenic processes in EAE and MS and expand our understanding of the recovery and healing mechanisms stimulated by DRQ therapy that may also be applicable to other CNS conditions of interest to the VA, including stroke, methamphetamine use disorder and traumatic brain injury.

PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance to Public Health: Sleep apnea patients with excessive daytime sleepiness are at highest risk for crashes related to drowsy driving. This proposal aims to identify the brain regions most impacted by sleep apnea and understand the underlying causes of individual differences in impact of sleep apnea. The long-term goal of this K25 is for Dr. Parekh to become an independent quantitative investigator capable of using cutting-edge mathematical tools to develop night-time biomarkers for daytime sleepiness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus is the causal agent of Kaposi sarcoma, a cancer that is very common in immunocompromised people (such as HIV/AIDS and transplant patients). We have designed a vaccine based on virus-like particles, with a goal to elicit antibody-mediated immune responses in three pre-clinical animal models (wild-type mice, humanized mice, and common marmoset monkeys). We expect to generate data that support future testing of our vaccine in humans as a candidate to prevent Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus infection and its associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Zebrafish exhibit a remarkable ability to regenerate complex tissues such as heart and spinal cord. This project examines the molecular mechanisms of skin regeneration in zebrafish, particularly the central process of re- epithelialization, in order to develop novel regenerative strategies for human wound healing. A career development plan is proposed that supports the transition of the applicant, a plastic and reconstructive surgeon with a background in biomedical engineering, to an independent investigator in this field.

PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): We will continue to study the role of mitochondrial DNA metabolism in NLRP3 inflammasome activation and the effect of NRF2 on macrophage polarization. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In chronic kidney disease, fracture is common and morbid, but with complex pathophysiology that is often difficult to detect. Bone biopsy at the iliac crest is the gold standard method to evaluate bone pathology, but is infrequently available to clinicians, and is poorly correlated with other bone sites. We propose to evaluate bone pathology at the hip in kidney patients who undergo surgical repair for a hip fracture to determine the risk factors for different bone pathologies, biomarkers that can identify these pathologies non-invasively, and test the significance of these biomarkers for future fracture risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wnt signaling is a critical regulator of development, and de-regulation of this pathway results in severe developmental defects, loss of tissue homeostasis and cancer. The proposed research will advance our understanding of Wnt signaling by generating and characterizing new tools to manipulate this pathway in human pluripotent stem cells, organoid cultures and whole animals. The long-term goal of these studies is to gain a better understanding of how Wnt signaling controls embryonic development, thereby enabling strategies for the generation of mature cells types, tissues and organs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Basal-like breast cancer has the worst prognosis of all breast cancer types. One of the hurdles to identifying effective targeted therapies is the uncertainty about how the disease arises in the first place. By examining cancer-prone tissues before tumor onset, we hope to identify the path(s) that cells take en route to becoming a basal-like cancer.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative All current hormonal treatments for advanced prostate cancer target androgens or their action. Although initially effective, these treatments eventually fail because androgens are regenerated, stimulating tumor cell growth. Our data suggest tumors regenerate androgens by using a previously unrecognized pathway that is not affected by current treatments; this project will determine the role of this alternative pathway and is expected to lead to an entirely new prostate cancer treatment.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed program will train researchers at the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) and the Ministry of Health (MOH) to conduct locally relevant research that will improve the lives of adolescent girls and women affected by HIV in Kenya and other parts of sub-Saharan Africa. Research will be focused on finding ways to implement interventions that have been proven to work and can directly lead to changes in guidelines, clinical practices and policies. PHR: Project Narrative Substantial research evaluates the contribution of one’s personal socio-economic status (SES) on risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRDs) and outcomes after the onset of ADRDs, although in many global settings, adult children may be their older parents’ most critical socio-economic resource. In this project, we will evaluate the impact of adult children’s education on parents’ cognitive decline, risk for dementia/cognitive impairment, and on longevity, physical functioning, and psychosocial outcomes for older parents after dementia/cognitive impairment onset using data on over 156,000 older adults from global aging cohort studies representing 20 countries in North and Central America, Asia, and Europe. We will additionally evaluate the economic and non-economic factors that explain any apparent associations, and how these associations differ for subgroups of older adults, including by their own level of educational attainment and features of their country’s social policies.

PHR: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a serious complication of injuries and infections, including influenza, COVID-19, and future viruses, and has a high rate of death and disability. There are no effective medications available to treat ARDS. We used a computer to help identify potential new drugs to treat ARDS called substrate- and function-selective p38 inhibitors. We previously identified one of these inhibitors, UM101, which had lung-protective activity. We then modified this compound to improve its lung protective effects and started clinical testing. We have now identified four new compounds with much better effects than our original. We will modify these new compounds as we did for UM101 and test them for lung- protective effects to develop a pipeline of potential lung-protective drugs. Relevance to VA: The Veteran patient population is older and has many of the recognized risk factors for death from ARDS (influenza- and COVID-19-induced ARDS).

ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: More than 7% of the US population and 20% of our Veterans have diabetes. Diabetes increases the risk of stroke and dementia, both of which are leading causes of disability. However, we do not know why. We think diabetes impairs the overall health of cells that line up the blood vessels in the brain. When this happens, other cells in the brain are affected and cannot function well. This project will determine how we can improve the health of small vessels in the brain and whether this improves stroke outcomes and dementia by using innovative therapies that can be easily implemented in patients. Thus, the results are expected to have a significant impact on human health and the VA mission.

PHR: For centuries, malaria has been considered a significant threat to the health and effectiveness of military forces that conduct operations in malaria-endemic areas. In modern times, malaria remains a major medical threat to U.S. military capability for operations in any environment where malaria is endemic, to be specific, the developing tropical and subtropical regions of the world. Malaria and antimalarials represent two of the most common biological and chemical exposures of US veterans. Our drug development project strongly aligns and compliments with the VA’s mission to improve Veterans’ well-being through supporting/conducting preclinical research. We seek to develop safe and effective antimalarials that can be used in all individuals, including our military service men and women. The resultant advantages of avoiding drug toxicity, febrile illness and complex medical management during deployment are self-evident, as are the benefits to both short and long-term health of the soldiers.

PHR: Project Narrative Preliminary experiments in the non-human primate model revealed that most of the detected SIV infected cells during the rebound phase after antiretroviral treatment interruption are of myeloid origin. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal addresses the significant clinical issue of bacterial otitis media (OM). We developed a new mouse model to investigate how specific host innate immune responses and the microbiome impact clearance of the major OM pathogen Streptococcus pneumoniae following invasion of the middle ear. The goal of these studies is to identify critical factors which promote S. pneumoniae clearance from the middle ear in order to inform the development of novel immunotherapy and probiotic-based approaches for the treatment of bacterial OM.

ORG_NAME: CLEMENT J. ZABLOCKI VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Our military Veterans disproportionately suffer from breathing-related diseases that result in persistently increased levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the body (chronic hypercapnia). The chronic hypercapnia alone may lead to poor quality of life, reduced life expectancy, and decreased neurologic (cognitive) function, and can become worse when patients acquire an acute illness. Yet, little is known about how the breathing and the brain progressively adapt to chronic hypercapnia. Here, we will utilize a human-like animal model (goats) and apply cutting-edge approaches to measure changes in gene expression within the brain that are altered during different stages of chronic hypercapnia, how these gene expression patterns may be further altered when the hypercapnia is made worse, and if brain inflammation plays an important role in the adaptive response to hypercapnia. This approach will provide unprecedented insights into critical signaling pathways in the brain that are altered during hypercapnia, and thus provide new targets for therapeutic intervention in patients suffering from these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative  The mosquito disease vector, Aedes aegypti, is troubling because it spreads viruses that cause diseases such as dengue, yellow fever, and Zika, which infect >100,000,000 people/year. Once this daytime biting mosquito senses CO2 from our breadth, they then home in on people using visual and other cues. Despite the importance of vision in finding humans, our understanding of the visual mechanisms that mosquitoes use to find people are largely unknown. The goal of this application is to fill this gap. This project lays the conceptual foundation for devising innovative approaches to limit the ability of mosquitoes in detecting hosts for blood meals.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Birth defects are a leading cause of death and morbidity in children around the world. The David W. Smith Workshop on Malformations and Morphogenesis has a history of being the primary forum where clinicians and basic scientists exchange information on the pathogenesis of human malformations. This proposal is a request to provide continuing support for the David W. Smith Workshop in the form of travel stipends for residents, fellows, junior faculty and a select number of plenary speakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Function and regulatory mechanisms of the Wnt5a-Ror morphogenetic pathway PI: Ho Wnt5a-Ror signaling is an evolutionarily conserved developmental signaling pathway that controls cell and tissue morphogenesis. Genetic mutations that disrupt the pathway cause congenital birth defects. Our research aims to delineate the cell biological functions and regulatory mechanisms of the pathway and how these fundamental processes are perturbed in Wnt5a-Ror driven human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative African Americans with sickle cell disease (SCD) and co-existing kidney disease have an increased risk of mortality. Recent genetic studies have shown a causal association of apolipoprotein L1 gene (APOL1) polymorphisms with markedly increased risk for development of kidney disease in African Americans. The proposed research aims to 1) elucidate the association between APOL1 as well as other selected genetic modifiers in the development and progression of chronic kidney disease in individuals with SCD and 2) to generate a validated multi-gene genetic risk profile to identify individuals at increased risk of chronic kidney disease which will set the stage for future clinical studies evaluating novel disease-modifying therapies.

PHR: Public Health Relevance: HIV-1 Neurotoxicity: Mechanism & Modulation by Cannabinoids HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND) results from impaired synaptic communication. This proposal describes experiments to determine how the HIV protein Tat impairs the endocannabinoid system, an intrinsic mechanism that protects against excess excitatory synaptic activity. Studies that evaluate the consequences of these changes on network and cognitive function will guide the development of drugs to improve cognitive function in HAND and provide insight into potential untoward effects of marijuana in patients with HAND.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA viruses, such as hepatitis C virus (HCV) and dengue virus (DENV), encompass both established and emerging pathogens, and cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide remaining a constant threat to global public health. The proposed study will define new host pathways exploited by RNA viruses such as HCV and DENV that could form the basis of new antiviral therapies to limit viral infection. In addition, it will describe new mechanisms of regulation of the RNA modification m6A that will enable new understanding into a host of human diseases that are caused by altered gene expression and regulated by RNA modifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The immune system changes profoundly with progressive age, leaving the elderly susceptible to cancer, infection and tissue inflammation. Immune aging occurs prematurely in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and is associated with defects in DNA repair and with reprogramming of cellular metabolism. Here, we study the role of mitochondria and of mitochondrial DNA repair in immune aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Aerosol-generating procedures are medical procedures that can potentially produce pathogen-laden aerosols that pose a risk to healthcare providers. This has become a signiﬁcant issue as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, but it is crucial that the risks associated with speciﬁc procedures can be evaluated in a rigorous way not just for the current pandemic but for any future disease outbreaks as well. New tools are needed to assess these risks and develop mitigation strategies, and the primary focus of this exploratory project is to develop such a tool and use it to evaluate risk for several key procedures.

PHR: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is a deadly disease with increasing incidence in the veteran population. As the five-year survival rate for this disease remains extremely low, there is an urgent need to uncover the mechanisms underlying how pancreatic cancer cells become aggressive and resistant to standard therapies. PDAC is characterized by an abundant tumor microenvironment which supports resistance to chemotherapy. The tumor immune microenvironment, and myeloid cells in particular, have been highly implicated in chemoresistance. Utilizing pancreatic cancer patients at the Ann Arbor VA Healthcare System, this proposal aims to uncover the mechanisms of chemoresistance leveraging single-cell RNA sequencing, patient-derived organoid culture, and biospecimen acquisition of longitudinal matched human biospecimens to identify ways to treat therapy-refractory patients in this deadly disease.

ORG_NAME: VA NORTHERN CALIFORNIA HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounts for 80-85% of lung cancer, which is the leading cause of cancer- related deaths in the US veterans and general population. Molecularly targeted therapy and immunotherapy are two recent major breakthroughs in NSCLC. Each treatment modality benefits about 20% of NSCLC patient populations that can be enriched by a molecular or immunologic biomarker. We and others have shown that synthetic high affinity integrin ligands can be used to improving the diagnosis, imaging and drug delivery to lung cancer. The objective of this proposal is to optimize and characterize peptide ligands for targeting integrins in lung cancer. Our project has immediate translational potential in improving drug delivery and clinical assays currently used for molecular and immune biomarkers in lung cancer patients receiving molecularly targeted and/or immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy, a step forward to precision cancer care in lung cancer.

PHR: This project will study the role of caveolin and protein kinase A (PKA) in protecting the heart from diabetic  stress. We will explore the specific role of the caveolin/PKA dyad in various cellular locations and determine if  these sites are critical to the pathology in the diabetic heart. Both proteins are involved in regulating cellular  functions at the plasma membrane and in mitochondria. How these two specific compartment in a cell are  impacted in the setting of diabetes will be the focus of our studies. We will define molecular insights and  develop an approach to define and test specific therapeutic approaches to limit cardiac dysfunction in the  setting of diabetes.

PHR: Project Narrative Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma patients are resistant to current standard of care therapies, including RCHOP, and their tumors over-express an oncogenic microRNA, miR-155. In this proposal, we will develop next generation chemically modified and highly active antisense peptide nucleic acids (PNAs) for potent inhibition of miR-155 in mouse models of lymphoma, both genetically engineered and patient-derived. The proposal is built on the collaborative work of a team of experienced investigators with complementary expertise in pH-dependent peptide delivery to tumors, PNA design and synthesis, and mouse models of microRNA-driven malignancies, with the goal of developing this novel class of highly targeted anti-neoplastic agents for further clinical development.

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) affect Veterans at a disproportionate rate. IBD results from a complex interaction among the patient’s intestinal tract, gut microbiota and environmental factors such as diet. Pomegranate extract (PomX) and its gut microbiome metabolite urolithin A (UA) decreased the abundance of pathogens associated with IBD and reduced intestinal inflammation. Individual’s capability of producing UA depends on his/her gut microbiota. Furthermore, the capability is linked with chronic disease risks that may determines individual response to diet intervention. Therefore, we are proposing to evaluate the efficacy of PomX in reducing IBD symptoms in mice with and without UA producing capability separately. Results from our studies will be a premise for future clinical studies to explore the use of dietary PomX/UA supplements as alternative and adjuvant therapy based on individual gut microbiome status to improve gut mucosa inflammation in IBD, thus reduce the use of immune-suppressing medications in patients with mild to moderately active IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative To function normally, cells must coordinate fat or lipid metabolism and much of this coordinating occurs in an organelle called the endoplasmic reticulum. We recently discovered the biochemical reaction of an enzyme in this cell compartment called FIT2, which is required for health of cells or metabolic tissues, such as the liver. The projects of this proposal are aimed at understanding how this enzyme works to coordinate cellular lipid metabolism, how cells and tissues malfunction when the enzyme is deficient, and how reduced levels of this enzyme relates to metabolic disease and cancer metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Isoform switch occurs frequently in cancer, and in this application we will investigate the oncogenic role of Tet1 alternative isoform in the development of Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS), a hematological malignant disease. In addition, we will determine the molecular mechanisms that mediate the function of Tet1 isoform in hematopoietic stem progenitor cells (HSPCs). PHR: Emerging adults (ages 18-25) consume alcohol at higher rates than any other age group. The social and health consequences of alcohol misuse are greatest among emerging adults who are not college students or graduates of four-year colleges, many of whom also experience poverty, elevated stress, and a lack of behavioral alternatives to alcohol use. We will evaluate a promising intervention approach for non-student emerging adults that attempts to reduce alcohol use by decreasing stress and increasing engagement in positive and goal-directed activities that provide meaningful alternatives to alcohol use.

We will use in-vitro and in-vivo assays, human tissue samples and a mouse animal model to test our hypothesis.
