PHR: Project Narrative Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) is a primary cause of chronic liver diseases in western nations. Our current proposal focuses on our new discovery that a paracrine signaling between acetylcholine-producing immune cells in the liver and CHRNA2 expressed in hepatocytes, plays an adaptive/protective role in the context of ALD. Insights gained from proposed studies may lead to new therapeutic targets counteracting human liver diseases caused by chronic excessive alcohol consumption.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure, the fastest growing cardiovascular condition in the United States, is associated with significant symptom burden. The results of this study will shed light on our understanding of the role of biological and physiological mechanisms in explaining heart failure symptoms, particularly groups of co-occurring symptoms, over time. The knowledge generated from this study will be used to develop personalized symptom management interventions for adults with heart failure.

PHR: Project Narrative Two-thirds of all veterans are 55 years of age or older. Sarcopenia is a syndrome that effects approximately 25% of the U.S. population over the age of 70 characterized by progressive loss of skeletal muscle mass and strength with an increased risk of adverse outcomes such as physical disability, poor quality of life and even death. Loss of motor neuron innervation to the muscle (denervation) is a major contributor to sarcopenia. Our data shows that lipid hydroperoxide generation is significantly greater in denervated muscle and aged muscle when compared to sham or young controls, respectively. When we reduce lipid hydroperoxides or slow the generation of lipid hydroperoxides in denervated muscle we can slow muscle mass loss. In this proposal, we will define potential mechanisms by which lipid hydroperoxides trigger sarcopenia, and identify therapeutic targets to treat sarcopenia in veterans.

PHR: Dysregulation of sex steroid synthesis and secretion is a leading cause of infertility in both male and females. Infertility affects 1 in every 6 couples, with male infertility playing a primary factor in a third of all cases. Moreover, infertility affects about 10 percent of the female population (6.1 million) in the United States; about 100,000 female Veterans of reproductive age. Considering the number of men and women who suffer from infertility and secondary affects associated with dysregulation of sex steroid biogenesis understanding mechanisms that regulate PKA signaling and mobilization of substrate for steroid production hold great potential to positively impact reproductive health and overall quality of life. This research proposal centers on the identification of the molecular mechanisms responsible for transmitting signals from the outside environment to the mitochondria, initiating changes in mitochondrial structure and function, and then translating molecular responses into changes in steroid biosynthesis.

PHR: Project Narrative Numerous veterans suffer from advanced heart failure, a condition for which cardiac transplantation remains a preferred therapy. Outcomes after heart transplantation are severely limited by primary graft dysfunction, an inflammatory condition that occurs early after transplantation and is attributable to ischemia reperfusion injury. Primary graft dysfunction is characterized by infiltration of innate immune cells, such as neutrophils and monocytes into the transplanted heart. Our laboratory has developed intravital imaging approaches that has allowed us to define cellular and molecular requirements for leukocyte trafficking into cardiac grafts. In this grant, we propose to study how donor cell populations and signaling pathways regulate the recruitment of immune cells to hearts after transplantation. Targeting these pathways will provide novel avenues to ameliorate primary graft dysfunction and improve outcomes after heart transplantation.

PHR: Stroke is a devastating disorder and a leading cause of death and long-term disability in elderly veterans, as currently no therapy is available to alleviate post-stroke neurological deficits. The proposed study will explore bexarotene as a promising therapy for ischemic stroke. We will investigate whether bexarotene protects against ischemic brain injury and improves long-term neurological outcomes after experimental stroke in aged mice of both sexes. The studies proposed will also use state-of-the art approaches, comprehensive and long-term assessment of neurological functions, and aged subjects to gain novel mechanistic insights into the role of bexarotene in microglia and macrophage responses after ischemic stroke. This information will be valuable for future development of new stroke therapy for military men and women as well as elderly civilians.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New discoveries in genomics depend in large part upon the exploration of many large experimental datasets and diverse genome annotations. Researchers face fundamental analysis bottlenecks caused by the fact that existing “genome arithmetic” algorithms, software and data format are incapable of scaling to the size and complexity of modern genomics experiments. We therefore propose to develop innovative analysis techniques and data formats that will provide the genomics research community with scalable, reliable tools for exploring and interpreting tomorrow’s genomics experiments.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aggression is a social behavior that is vital for survival and reproduction. Though most mental health patients are not violent, pathological, high levels of aggression are common across mental health disorders that affect millions of Americans. In order to improve our ability to prevent and treat these disorders, this study will define the experience-dependent changes in neural circuits that generate persistent pathological aggression.

PHR: This proposal entitled `Regulation of hippocampal function by central and peripheral IRS signaling', brings our core focus on insulin receptor substrates to bear on the medically important problem of how insulin resistance and diabetes promote cognitive decline. Our proposal investigates the function of the insulin receptor substrates in the hippocampus and in peripheral tissues to regulate cognitive function in aged mice during progressive metabolic disease. Our approach employs mice with unique patterns of Irs1 and Irs2 expression to distinguish effects of neuronal versus peripheral insulin signaling. Our innovative experimental models can reveal new mechanistic insights that can guide development of targeted strategies to prevent cognitive decline during diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children from disadvantaged backgrounds, on average exhibit disparities in academic achievement and cognitive development, compared to their peers from higher socioeconomic status (SES) backgrounds. The proposed studies will investigate the role of specific aspects of children’s early language input on the development of neural networks supporting the development of language, executive functioning, and social cognition, and how these may ultimately drive SES differences in academic achievement. Findings from this work have the potential to inform maximally impactful interventions to reduce achievement gaps and improve cognitive outcomes for children from all backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal and perinatal hypoxic-ischemic brain injury (HIBI) is a major cause of death and neurological damage in infants and children, and there is an unmet need for therapeutic options to prevent or reverse these effects. The plasma membrane protein TRPM7 is known to control critical cellular processes involved in oxygen- deprivation of the brain and to protect the brain from damage when suppressed, and the only known specific and potent inhibitor of TRPM7 is waixenicin A. The current proposal engages an interdisciplinary team to lay the groundwork for a viable therapeutic treatment option developed from waixenicin A based on this mechanism.

PHR: NARRATIVE The present application will test new models by which certain highly-flexible regions in proteins help control when and where DNA replication begins, and how chromosomes are organized inside cells. The proposed studies are pertinent to understanding basic mechanisms of human diseases such as cancer or certain forms of developmental dwarfism that arise from defects in the timing of division and genetic stability.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to develop Galaxy platform into the comprehensive data analysis medium connecting biomedical experts across the full spectrum of skill sets, scientific domains, and research practices. For tool developers it will provide a community-supported mechanism for deploying tools before a wide audience of users.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insufficient and poor sleep is pervasive among individuals with shoulder conditions requiring surgical intervention. Shortened sleep and increased sleep disturbances induce an outsized inflammatory reaction, which sensitizes the nociceptive response and may increase susceptibility for developing chronic post-surgical pain and the subsequent need for prolonged postoperative opioid therapy. Therefore, this prospective study will utilize daily sleep data, collected from wearable devices, and inflammatory markers to examine associations with patient-reported pain outcomes and opioid utilization up to 3 months after shoulder surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cerebral palsy (CP) is the major neurodevelopmental disorder affecting physical function and we and others have shown that mutations in single genes can disrupt normal brain development and lead to CP. Recessively inherited CP accounts for about one-third of genetic cases and features neurologically-healthy carrier parents and affected children who inherit a mutant copy of a given gene from both their mother and their father. This discovery based initiative will study highly genetically-informative families from Africa, the Middle East and Southeast Asia in order to discover CP-associated genes exhibiting recessive inheritance; such discoveries are anticipated to improve CP diagnosis and care by bringing molecular insights to the CP community.

PHR: Project Narrative We propose to establish the University of Pittsburg-Mozambique HIV Research Training Program (Pitt- MozHRTP), which has as its primary goal the enhancement of research capacity in the areas of COVID-19, cardiovascular diseases, and diabetes in people with HIV. This will be accomplished by an expert, multidisciplinary team of research mentors and excellent training opportunities at the University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, USA and the University of Stellenbosch, Cape Town, South Africa. By the end of the five-year funding period, we anticipate that we will have made a huge impact on HIV research capacity in Mozambique.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Noise-induced hearing loss affects almost a billion people worldwide yet is currently untreatable. Our research seeks to enhance our understanding of the protection mechanisms that prevent noise-induced hearing loss. The results of this project are expected to open the door for the development of novel therapeutics.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) involve varied and progressive interactions between different aggregating proteins and brain cell types. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis (OA) is a chronic and disabling condition characterized by joint pain, stiffness, and cartilage degradation. Current treatments focus on managing pain and do not alter disease fate. In this project, we will examine how controlling the activity of protein phosphatases contributes to joint pain and the presence of neurons in the joint.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Understanding the rules which guide how neuronal patterns are transformed and utilized by downstream structures to produce behavior is critical for our understanding of how abstract patterns become actions and how such transformations are affected in disease. The present proposal examines how neuronal population patterns in upstream circuits are ‘read out’ by downstream observer circuits/mechanisms in the entorhinal cortex – hippocampus - neocortex loop by combining large-scale electrophysiology, optogenetics and imaging in behaving rodents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative These studies have the potential to discover novel epithelial functions of Notch signaling, novel Notch2 and Jag1 interacting proteins, novel genes regulated by Notch signaling, and to identify genetic enhancers/suppressor of JAG1/NOTCH2 mutation dependent kidney disease. We will progress towards finding molecular therapies to improve the health of humans suffering from kidney diseases due to mutations in JAG1 or NOTCH2, like the patients with Alagille Syndrome. In addition, understanding how Notch signaling regulates epithelial cell processes will have a broad impact on understanding Notch signaling as an epithelial tumor suppressor in certain cancers of the kidney, lung, skin, and head and neck.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compounds that promote neuroplasticity, such as serotonergic psychedelics, have enormous potential for treating a variety of neuropsychiatric diseases including addiction. Recently, our group discovered that it is possible to engineer non-hallucinogenic analogs of psychedelics capable of promoting neuroplasticity and producing sustained antiaddictive effects after a single administration. The research described here seeks to develop high-throughput methods for identifying such compounds with the ultimate goal of developing new treatments for substance use disorders.

PHR: The activity of cells and neural circuits are altered in Alzheimer's disease (AD), and may represent a point of therapeutic intervention to affect disease progression. We recently found that manipulating oscillations in the gamma range with noninvasive auditory and visual sensory stimuli promotes neuroimmune interactions and alleviates AD-associated pathology in multiple disease mouse models, but the mechanisms by which GENUS promotes neuroimmune interactions are not clear. We will investigate the effects and potential mechanisms by which GENUS impacts the cellular and molecular responses of neuroimmune interactions, particular those mediated by microglia, and how microglial AD risk genes, APOE4 and TREM2, modifies GENUS-mediated neuroimmune activity that could affect AD pathology and cognitive function.

PHR: Project Narrative Short tandem repeats (STRs) are repetitive DNA sequences that cause dozens of genetic diseases in humans and are difficult to sequence and interpret, leaving individuals with STR-associated disease undiagnosed. This proposal will establish a genetic diagnosis for hundreds of patients, while searching for new STR disease loci. To accomplish this, we will develop new computational approaches and call STRs across the genome in thousands of individuals to establish a population-scale STR catalog, with an emphasis on diverse and under- served populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and associated metabolic disease, including type 2 diabetes, are a public health crisis; the risks of which are elevated in military Veterans. Although invasive, bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for sustained weight loss, and it also improves glycemic control and other comorbidities in obese patients. This innovative research project will examine the novel role of intestinal-derived Fibroblast Growth Factor 15 (FGF15) in the regulation of body composition and glucose metabolism following bariatric surgery. The findings from these studies have high potential to identify new interventions in targeting obesity, metabolic disease, and for the preservation of lean mass and bone density after weight loss surgery.

ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Emphysema, a chronic and debilitating lung disease for which the primary risk factors are a prior history of cigarette smoking, male sex and advancing age, is commonly diagnosed in US Veterans. Histologically and functionally, emphysema is associated with loss of terminal lung alveoli which comprise alveolar epithelial cells, capillary endothelial cells and septal fibroblasts, the latter providing trophic and structural support to the alveolar epithelium. Little is known about the effects of cigarette smoke on fibroblasts or how this may affect the survival and function of the alveolar epithelium. This application seeks to address this fundamental knowledge gap and identify strategies to prevent lung tissue destruction in emphysema.

ORG_NAME: SOUTH TEXAS VETERANS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Aging-related bone degeneration is a major healthcare challenge for America's growing population of aging Veterans. Changes in bone mass and structure occur with age and are common in both women and men, resulting in increased risk for debilitating pain, bone fracture, and delayed healing. With aging, resident stem cells in bone lose their ability to maintain the tissue and bone degeneration takes place over time. My preliminary results suggest that during aging, the level of a protein, Cyr61 (also known as CCN1), becomes depleted in bone. The proposed research will investigate this protein and determine if it's required for normal function of bone-specific stem cells and whether replenishing it during aging restores their function in bone. The results gained from this study may provide a novel approach for reversing bone degeneration during aging or stimulating bone repair after injury.

ORG_NAME: VA NEW JERSEY HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Airborne- and droplet-transmitted diseases are common during military deployments. Developing efficacious vaccines against infectious diseases is thus essential for protecting troops in service as well as veterans. Our proposed study directly addresses this need, by advancing the understanding of TFH cells at new frontiers, i.e., elucidating differential requirements for costimulation signals by immunization and viral infection, and connecting costimulation signals, nuclear factors, chromatin and transcriptomic changes with TFH functions. We expect to yield essential information on tailoring TFH activity to provide optimal B cell help, and hence provide paradigm-shifting rationales for enhancing vaccine design.

PHR: Project Narrative Approximately 65% of Veterans report pain in the last 3 months, and >50% of Veterans receiving care at VHA facilities report chronic pain. Opioid drugs are the first-line treatment for chronic pain but have many side effects. Here, we hypothesize that brain melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4Rs) are a promising novel non-opioid target for reducing nociception in individuals living with chronic inflammatory pain. More specifically, we will test the predictions that chronic inflammatory pain produces age-specific and sex-specific changes in nociception and pain avoidance. We predict that inflammatory pain will differentially alter MC4R expression & engage descending pain modulation circuits in adolescent and adult male and female rats. We will also test the predictions that MC4R antagonism and descending pain circuit stimulation rescue inflammatory pain effects and that intra-nasal drug delivery holds promise for translation into humans living with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental causes of cancer include chemicals and radiation, as well metabolites that are produced in response to environmental chemicals. These agents induce DNA damage that can be particularly detrimental during DNA replication and requires unique DNA repair processes to overcome. This project will investigate activation and functioning of these specialized DNA repair processes to understand how they mitigate environmental sources of DNA damage.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (NARRATIVE):      Rotaviruses are important causes of life- threatening diarrhea in the young. This proposal will help us understand  how  a  key  enzyme  of  rotavirus  functions  during  infection,  which  could  inform  antiviral  drug  design.  Thus,  the  proposed  research  is  relevant  to  the part  of  NIH's  mission  that  pertains  to  creating knowledge  that will  help to  reduce the burden of human disease.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic have been unequally felt by individuals and communities across the United States. To understand these patterns, we will create, integrate, and share data on neighborhood characteristics, both before and since the pandemic, that can be readily linked to existing survey or cohort studies at various levels of geography. This national neighborhood data resource will support the scientific community in understanding the mechanisms that may convey risk and resilience, particularly in underserved and vulnerable populations, and will allow us to more effectively prepare for the next public health emergency.

PHR: Stigma impedes every step along the HIV continuum of care, including uptake and adherence to antiretroviral therapy (ART). While intersectional stigma has become the focus of much research in high-income countries, far less is known about how intersectional stigma impacts the HIV continuum of care in low-income countries. This pre-doctoral training and research project leverages an existing research infrastructure to test a novel measure of intersectional stigma in relation to HIV treatment adherence among men and women living with HIV in South Africa.

PHR: Narrative Pancreatic cancer is one of the most deadly malignancies in the United States. In this highly collaborative study, a multidisciplinary team of investigators from the University of California at Davis, TargaGenix and Northeastern University, will collaborate to develop a clinically translatable nanoemulsion-based delivery system for our lead agent in combination with immunotherapy for effective treatment of pancreatic tumors. The proposed solution will lead to the development of a promising new combination anticancer therapeutic modality, especially against aggressive and highly metastatic diseases, such as pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep amount is highest during early stages of life, and sleep disturbances during this period can have adverse consequences, including increased risk of cognitive disorders later in life. The proposed research will investigate the function of sleep in a genetically identified simple circuit in young animals. This work will contribute to the understanding of the function of sleep in young animals and may help identify novel therapeutic targets for neurodevelopmental disorders.

PHR: T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) affects both children and adults. T-ALL shows a male predominance and is found in adult patients aged 20-60. This epidemiologic pattern closely fits the demographic of young Veterans. Although T-ALL is an uncommon cancer among Veterans, it has aggressive clinical features that make it difficult to treat. This grant proposes to study adult T-ALL from the perspective of the LMO2 oncogene, which is universally expressed in ETP-ALL and immature T-ALL, both are poor prognosis subtypes that are present in adult T-ALL patients. The specific aims of this grant address the unmet need of therapeutics for ETP and adult T-ALL through novel cutting-edge approaches. Since the LMO2 oncogene may very well be involved in other leukemias that affect Veterans, the findings from the proposed studies have the potential to be applied to multiple other cancers.

PHR: Cancer is the second leading cause of death among US veterans, and lung cancer is associated with the greatest mortality in these patients. Non-small cell lung cancers (NSCLC) represent the majority of lung cancers and carry a poor prognosis with a median survival of less than 12 months. Most patients present with unresectable disease, and current treatment options of chemotherapy and radiation are palliative at best. Our laboratory has identified key mechanisms specific to a particular mutation/ inactivation of tumor suppressor genes in NSCLCs, which are plausible and highly desired targets for the development of new and targeted anti-cancer therapeutics (precision medicine). This grant application explores these cellular mechanisms in depth with the goal of developing new therapeutics to combat NSCLC, and thereby, aid US Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 and influenza account for a substantial disease burden in the United States, and both show substantial disparities. The proposed research uses descriptive, non-experimental, and agent based-modeling to examine 1) neighborhood social determinants of COVID-19 and influenza acute care utilization (hospitalizations and Emergency Department visits) under varying contexts, 2) effects of two policies (paid sick leave and rent control) on these outcomes, and 3) develops hypothesis about the mechanisms linking two key social determinants, occupational exposures and housing overcrowding, and influenza disparities. Findings will advance our understanding of the social and policy drivers of infectious disease disparities and inform policies and interventions that can mitigate disparities in seasonal, endemic, and other potential future respiratory illness pandemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  The overall goal of this proposal is to develop novel vectors with which gene therapy of muscular dystrophies can be achieved with improved safety and efficacy. These vectors are derived from a virus that causes no known disease in humans, and therefore, are expected to be safer. Thus, the development of such a vector system for the potential treatment and cure of these debilitating human diseases has relevance to public health.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE  The incidence of obesity-associated breast cancers continues to rise, suggesting that current recommendations to maintaining a healthy body weight and increasing physical activity are not sufficient to decrease this risk at the population level. This proposal will determine if preventing accumulation of fat in abdominal regions could be a specific way to decrease the risk of obesity-related breast cancers during menopause. Results of these studies will have implications for all women with overweight/obesity entering menopause, who are at increased risk for postmenopausal breast cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative Home healthcare (HHC) is an important source of care for older Americans with multiple chronic conditions, including those historically at risk for health disparities. Our prior work indicates that infection prevention and control (IPC) in the HHC setting is sub-optimal and HHC agencies were not prepared for the pandemic. This study will be the first comprehensive examination of how HHC IPC changed from pre-pandemic to 2024, associations between IPC practices and health disparities, and will generate evidence-based recommendations to help HHC agencies for future public health infectious emergencies.

PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance) This project will provide critical and detailed information regarding the brain basis of human higher cognitive functioning, such as the control of attention, and whether such functioning can be enhanced through brain electrical stimulation techniques that are low-cost, non-invasive, and safe. This information has high relevance for public health, in that it will be used to identify key neural and behavioral markers that can be used as targets in future intervention efforts directed towards individuals with mental health disorders associated with cognitive impairment (e.g., schizophrenia, dementia, autism).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Childhood-onset mitochondrial disease associated with mutations in YARS2 is clinically pleiotropic, likely due to tissue-specific effects of mutations on nutrient sensing and cell signaling. To test this hypothesis, we will use the most clinically severe case known to date as a model to generate a pair of human subject-derived iPSC and control lines. Analysis of transcriptome-wide changes in gene expression specific to the subject line in iPSC- differentiated disease relevant cell types will identify the impact of YARS2 deficiency on nutrient-sensitive cell signaling as the underlying basis of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The IKK (I kappaB Kinase) complex, a large protein complex composed of two catalytic subunits and an adapter scaffolding coiled-coil NEMO subunit that controls cellular responses to a large number of diverse extracellular and environmental stimuli to induce transcription factor NF-kappaB. This proposal will investigate how the larger assembly of the IKK complex play an essential role in signal propagation by allowing the NEMO subunit to undergo structural changes required for IKK activation. This proposal will also investigate if the peptides derived from the IKK complex can be used to control systemic inflammation and collagen induced arthritis in mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are critical regulators of brain function and potential therapeutic targets for a host of neurological diseases and disorders. However, our knowledge of astrocytic function is highly incomplete, and technologies are critically needed to effectively manipulate astrocyte activity with spatiotemporal precision. Developing such technologies has a broad impact to the study of the roles of astrocytes in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) is a leading preventable cause of mental retardation in the United States that develops in children whose mothers engaged into considerable alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Currently, there is no readily available cure for FASD, and the goal of our research is to establish the role of alcohol damage to fetal brain vessels in development of this pathology. If successful, our research will introduce a much needed pathway for therapeutic intervention(s) against FASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop a 3D ultrasonic shear wave elasticity imaging system and use it to non-invasively measure the mechanical properties of skeletal muscle and to determine their relationship to muscle health; this system will ultimately be used to assess muscular deﬁcits associated with neuromuscular diseases and to determine how well therapeutic treatments are working and when they should be modiﬁed, which will both improve treatment efﬁcacy and reduce the number of muscle biopsies performed in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Congenital infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a leading cause of childhood deafness and permanent neurologic impairment worldwide, with approximately 40,000 cases occurring annually in the U.S. This project will include detailed studies of CMV-specific immunity in infants infected in utero and in early childhood and will identify immune correlates of viral control and clinical sequelae. Insights from these studies will lead to a better understanding of the cellular and molecular immune processes that underlie the age-related vulnerability of the human fetus to viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection causes an increased risk of complications and death after hematopoietic cell transplantation. Recent studies suggest that new medications for the prevention of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) after transplant may promote the development of immunity against CMV; however, it is unclear whether these new GVHD preventative drugs can promote CMV immunity in the era of modern CMV prevention. This proposal will seek to answer this question, using cutting edge technology and analytical methods, in order to inform management of CMV in the context of new and future cancer treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative African Americans (AAs) have significantly higher rates and earlier onset of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) relative to White Americans; however, we lack a thorough understanding of how individual and neighborhood factors and their changes over the lifecourse contribute to ADRD risk in AAs. The current proposal capitalizes on an ongoing, longitudinal study to examine the impact of changing neighborhood conditions and the role of risk and protective factors in the lived experience of AAs and their influence on cognitive function and ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to define the role of the SigmaR1-IRE1a-XBP1 signaling axis in astrocytes during CNS inflammation. To achieve this goal, we propose to apply spatial transcriptomics, scRNA-seq, and genetic and pharmacologic perturbations to the analysis of MS patient samples and murine disease models. In summary, this project investigates a novel molecular pathway in astrocytes using cutting edge techniques to define basic mechanisms that control CNS inflammation and identify novel therapeutic targets.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research determines how newly designed muscarinic drug compounds enhance cognition, motivation, and problem solving with high efficacy and without dose-limiting side effects that accompany existing drugs. Our research will elucidate how these drug-induced pro-cognitive and pro-motivational effects relate to neurochemical and activity changes of interneurons in the prefrontal cortex and the striatum. The results have the potential to identify the cell-type specific mechanisms with which advanced novel drug compounds enhances cognition and motivation, thereby proposing novel treatment strategies for mental disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women are more vulnerable to the rewarding effects of cocaine and more rapidly progress from initial  use to dependence than men but the neurobiological mechanisms that contribute to these differences yet to be  determined. This project will use a combination of single-cell transcriptomics, blood hormone level assays,  pharmacology, and RNAscope to investigate how sex steroids and nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs)  alpha 5 (α5) contribute to sex differences in cocaine self-administration. The overall goal of this project is to  identify the effects of a history of cocaine self-administration on sex steroids and nAChRs expression and to test  the hypothesis that decreased nAChR α5 in the dHIPP produced by decreased progesterone levels promote  cocaine self-administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal traffic-related air pollution (TRAP) exposure has been consistently linked with altered child neurodevelopment, and placental dysfunction is central to these effects. We propose the first study on the impact of TRAP on the placenta N6-methyladenosine (m6A) epitranscriptome and the ensuing effects on child neurodevelopment, using both population-based and mechanistic approaches. Our focus on the placenta an extraembryonic tissue that is key to early-life neurodevelopmental programming will lead to novel insight into the mechanisms governing the effects of prenatal TRAP exposure and child neurodevelopment and may uncover new molecular targets for prevention and treatment.

PHR: Public relevance Emotional well-being is critical for maintaining quality of life and preventing dementia among older adults. A thorough understanding of the brain mechanisms of emotional well-being as well as the relationship between emotional well-being and dementia will form the basis for identification of biomarkers and intervention strategies for promoting positive well-being and preventing dementia among older adults. The proposed network will strengthen the growth of multidisciplinary research and investigators to serve this need.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it investigates the normal and disease-related functions of tau, a key protein involved in Alzheimer's disease. This research will contribute to our knowledge of mechanisms of sporadic Alzheimer's disease and may lead to new therapeutic strategies to treat this devastating disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to seeking knowledge about the behavior of living systems and application of that knowledge to reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative High-risk human papillomaviruses (HPVs) cause essentially all cancers of the uterine cervix, as well as many other anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers. Despite the availability of highly effective prophylactic vaccines against HPV infection, cancers associated with HPV infection remain a major disease burden due to the limited use of the vaccine and the absence of vaccine benefit in people with current HPV infection. As elucidating the cellular basis of HPV infection may reveal valuable new strategies to combat HPV infection, in this proposal we propose to clarify a critical entry step during HPV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans born preterm have low nephron number and are at risk for acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease. We plan to use a mouse model of low nephron number to study the cellular and molecular basis of kidney disease in this population. Our goal is to discover prevention and treatment strategies for acute kidney injury and the development of chronic kidney disease in humans born preterm.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is relevant to public health because traumatic brain injury is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children and adolescents. The proposed study will develop an innovative poly-matching design (PMD) for comparative clinical effectiveness research (CER) and apply causal inference strategies to assess four acute medical management/therapies for pediatric traumatic brain injuries (TBI). The ultimate goal is to provide inno- vative methods for research related to emergency medical services for children (EMSC) and build the evidence base for clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminant potential (CHIP) is a common age-related conditions affecting over 50% of elderly individuals over 85 years of age that has been associated with inferior outcome in general population and solid tumor patients, higher incidence of cardiovascular disease and occasional progression to myelodysplastic syndromes and leukemia. The focus of this project is to identify the population at risk for transformation and non-malignant sequalae of CHIP, determine the impact of CHIP in bone marrow transplant donors on post-transplant outcome and define the role of CHIP in development and progression of non- hematologic cancers. If successful, our study will result in clinically relevant risk stratification leading to reduction of CHIP-related consequences and application of personalized therapeutic approaches, improved bone marrow donor selection process and implementation of preventative strategies in the future.

PHR: The increased expression of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) enhances the immune function of macrophages and neutrophils by altering their metabolism and increasing cell production of ATP. PHR: Project Narrative: Cell therapy using human hepatocyte-like cells (h-iHLCs) has the potential to address the unmet need for high quality and less invasive therapies to treat liver disease. PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE:  Managing predicted burnout in RNs is important because, despite RNs comprising half of the global health workforce, there is still a critical shortage of hospital-based RNs in the U.S. While the proposed project focuses on predicting burnout in RNs, the insights derived in this work could be potentially applied to other healthcare workers (e.g., clinicians, clinical support staff) and may translate to non-healthcare workforces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We recently discovered that small differences in bacterial susceptibility to TB drugs are important predictors of treatment outcome, but what drives those differences is not known. This project unites three labs with highly complementary expertise to interrogate how M. tuberculosis clinical strains respond to treatment. We will apply with leading edge approaches in genetics, metabolism, gene regulation and network-based modeling to reveal fundamental new knowledge about TB that could lead directly to shorter treatment times and better treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Inter-tissue communication is essential for organismal homeostasis. Our research is focused on the fundamental mechanisms by which bidirectional communication between the nervous system and the intestine regulates antioxidant activity through neuropeptide signaling. Our research will uncover new mechanisms by which reactive oxygen species regulate neuropeptide secretion, which may lead to the development of new therapies for neurodegenerative diseases linked to defective antioxidant homeostasis.

PHR: Relevance Opioid use disorder has become a real threat to our society. This proposal will focus on the development of highly selective mu opioid receptor modulators as novel opioid use disorder treatment by applying multidisciplinary tools, including drug discovery and development, medicinal chemistry, neuropharmacology, and behavioral pharmacology. The goal of this project is to identify clinical candidates as suitable treatments for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Understanding protein folding mechanisms is important for human health. This proposal investigates how a protein cotranslationally folds by developing and applying technology to image in real-time folding dynamics at the single mRNA level in living cells. Using a combination of advanced single-molecule fluorescence microscopy and novel intrabodies to distinguish unfolded and folded forms of proteins, I will study the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) to address the basic questions of when, where, and how CFTR folds in living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The emergence of new malaria parasites from primate reservoirs into human populations is an increasing threat to human health, particularly in Asia and South America, and a major barrier to malaria elimination. This proposal will inform the host and parasite genetic basis of malaria’s ability to shift hosts, leading to downstream drug targets and prediction of emerging parasites.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Latinx are at increased risk for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) compared with non- Hispanic whites. Bilingualism may reduce ADRD risk but prior studies lack detailed characterization of within- group differences among bilinguals such as age of second language (L2) acquisition, L2 proficiency, and frequency of dual language use and its relationship to cognition in the presence of neuropathology. The current study will elucidate mechanisms underlying the relationship among bilingualism, neuroimaging markers of pathology, and cognitive function, which has the potential to inform novel interventions to preserve cognitive function and reduce ADRD disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the success of genome-wide association studies (GWAS), our ability to predict genetic risk remains limited, especially for people of non-European ancestry. This research proposes to uncover, and correct, statistical biases in our inference of the genetic architecture of disease risk and study genetic risk factors in underrepresented non-European populations. The findings of this research will improve the applicability of clinical genetic research to a more diverse set of people and lead to an improved understanding of the fundamental architecture of disease risk in humans.

PHR: NARRATIVE The fields of neurology and neurosurgery are poised to make rapid advances in the treatment of neurological disorders, but the success of this endeavor depends on the availability of a cadre of academically based clinician scientists who are engaged in translational research, and who will catalyze the translation of advances between the laboratory and the bedside. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This past decade has been marked by a cessation in the previous steady decline of cardiovascular deaths, and potentially even a slight uptick, creating a public health imperative to better understand the causes and treatments for cardiovascular disease. Building on an exceptionally strong prior track record of academic training, this proposal seeks to train the next generation of investigators with modern techniques for cardiovascular research, including in new areas particularly relevant to the aging demographics of the American population, leveraging new insights into mechanisms of cardiovascular disease for all and especially for women, and the digital health revolution. Working with a diverse and experienced cohort of faculty preceptors, trainees will immerse themselves in both experiential/project-based learning as well as didactic training in critical elements of cardiovascular science, to emerge as future thought leaders to better understand, diagnose, and treat a broad spectrum of cardiovascular diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative  An in-depth Genomic Medicine education, as provided by a master’s degree, is needed to prepare the medical students for careers analyzing the human genome in academic research centers, government, and industry, including biotechnology firms, pharmaceutical companies, and clinical laboratories. Thus, there is a great need for master’s education programs that provide health professional and related trainees with the knowledge and skills required to manipulate, annotate, and interpret human genome data, and a foundation for pursuing genomics research. To address this need, we will leverage our evolving expertise in analysis of genomic data and education (Nara Sobreira, Joann Bodurtha, David Valle, Weiyi Mu, Nancy Hueppchen, Kim Doheny, Winston Timp, Xiao Peng, Jim Stevenson, Dane Witmer, Carolyn Applegate) and the unique tools and resources available at JHUSOM such as the ones offered by the Office of Online Education (Robert Kearns), by the Johns Hopkins Advanced Academic Programs (Robert Lessick), and PhenoDB Teaching Tool to develop a Genomic Medicine Master’s program that will address the expanding need for genomic literacy and create opportunities for these individuals to train others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 1 Narrative Excessive blood clotting is a major cause of heart attacks and strokes in the United States and also underlies ~25% of cancer-related death. Our research brings new concepts and methodologies to bear on understanding basic molecular mechanisms underlying the blood clotting reactions. Our findings will address important but unresolved aspects of function to yield novel strategies for interfering with the formation of life-threatening blood clots in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Coagulation enzymes form macromolecular complexes to modulate important biological processes that are critical to normal health but become dysregulated in disease. One critical pathway that needs to be exquisitely controlled for human life is the coagulation system as to much blood coagulation leads to thrombosis, pathological blood clotting, and potentially death if it occurs in vital organs whereas to little coagulation can result in life threatening bleeding. In this proposal we will explore how such coagulation protein interactions tightly regulate this essential blood coagulation process using combinatorial chemistry and chemical biology approaches to generate novel probes for these processes. The results of these studies will yield a more thorough understanding of blood coagulation and potentially new therapeutic agents to limit thrombosis and bleeding in acute care settings.

PHR: PROJECT 4-PROJECT NARRATIVE The formation of a blood clot following vascular injury is an essential defensive mechanism that is highly regulated. Some people have inherited bleeding disorders because they are missing essential clotting factors such as factor VIII, IX, of X. This proposal seeks to both better understand how these clotting factors work together in the regulation of blood coagulation and to use this improved understanding to develop new and better therapies for these bleeding disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The knowledge in basic neuroscience has grown exponentially over the past generation, but there is a gap in bringing those discoveries to patients with disorders of the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves. The Neurology, Neurosurgery, and Neuropathology Pittsburgh Research Education Program (N3-PREP) is designed to increase the number of well-prepared physician-neuroscientists from the University of Pittsburgh who will progress to being at the forefront of research that will ultimately reduce the burden of neurologic diseases. Our goal is to train the next generation of physician-neuroscientists in basic science, translational science, data science, and clinical (patient-oriented) research through a strongly mentored approach, in an environment ripe with physical and faculty resources across the translational spectrum of neuro-focused research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying cell-specific mitochondrial differences between and across cell types during autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) progression. We anticipate that similar to other conditions where mitochondria have central roles in disease pathogenesis, the proposed studies will identify contributions of mitochondrial dysfunction and transcriptional diversity to disease initiation and progression. These advances have the potential to transform the development of precision-targeted therapeutics and biomarkers for monitoring ADPKD, drug selection, and drug dosage; all unmet clinical ADPKD needs relevant to NIH’s mission of improving human health.

PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE The proposed Program is relevant to public health because it seeks to discover fundamental principles of cancer etiology, evolution, and evasion of response to therapy, focusing on the childhood malignancy neuroblastoma. The research is highly relevant to the NIH mission and the urgent unmet need of developing rational evidence- based therapeutic strategies to reduce the health burden of cancer. This integrated multi-disciplinary Program is designed to continue to catalyze improved cure rates with decreased morbidity for patients with high-risk neuroblastoma, and many advances will be applicable to the field of cancer in general.

PROJECT_TITLE: Discovering and Exploiting Mechanisms of Neuroblastoma Therapy Resistance

PHR: NARRATIVE Project 1 is relevant to public health because it seeks to discover the fundamental reasons why cancer becomes resistant to therapy by understanding solid tumor cellular heterogeneity and adaptation to modern therapies, within a Program focused on the childhood malignancy neuroblastoma. The research is highly relevant to the NIH mission and the urgent unmet need of developing rational evidence-based therapeutic strategies to reduce the health burden of high-risk neuroblastoma, and perhaps other human cancers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Targeting evolving therapy resistance

PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE Distinct adrenergic (ADR) and mesenchymal (MES) epigenetic states exist in NB, likely contributing to therapy resistance. We discovered that the MES state is associated with impaired responses to the immunotherapy dinutuximab, an FDA-approved antibody directed against GD2, a glycolipid on the surface of NB cells, and that the lysine methyl transferase EZH2 and the scaffolding protein MEN1 (menin) both regulate cell-surface GD2 levels in NB. Our proposal tests chromatin modifying compounds, including clinical inhibitors of EZH2 and menin, hypothesizing that these agents will transdifferentiate MES NB models into an ADR-like state, thereby increasing expression of targets critical to both small molecule inhibitors and to immunotherapies, leading to enhanced responses, meeting the NIH mission of improving patient outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Targeting neuroblastoma cell state plasticity

PHR: PROJECT 3 NARRATIVE Project 3 brings a unique perspective to the program project by focusing on external mechanisms (the tumor microenvironment) that – combined with intrinsic mechanisms (genetic and epigenetic alterations in tumor cells) - lead toward therapy resistance in neuroblastoma. The project has a focus on tumor-associated macrophages and cancer-associated fibroblasts that are a source of numerous inflammatory cytokines/chemokines activating TGFb-dependent and -independent pathways that promote the emergence of therapy resistant mesenchymal neuroblastoma cells. Discoveries made will lead to the preclinical testing of inhibitors of TGFb and JAK/STAT3 and to the development of TGFb resistant cellular therapies in combination with chemo-and immuno-therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly all aspects of biology and human disease are rooted in gene regulation. Our knowledge and abilities to understand, control, and rectify gene expression and mis-expression is fundamental to basic biological knowledge and medicine. We propose a continuation of our successful predoctoral training program to prepare a cadre of young scientists who excel in cross-disciplinary skills and address fundamental questions related to gene regulation processes and their impact on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transfusion Medicine, Classical Hematology, and Glycobiology are increasingly important, but under- subscribed, areas of medicine. We propose a new and comprehensive training program for trainees in these areas of research to become independent scientists who will pursue careers that advance science to improve the health of millions of people with blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Training Program in Basic Immunology at Washington University in Saint Louis seeks continued support (Years 46-50) to maintain a highly successful mechanism to support talented predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees, who aspire to become leaders in immunology research. The program faculty are highly accomplished scientists performing state-of-the-art immunology research in a premier world-class medical research institution. The Program has supported the careers of many of today's most successful immunology researchers, and its continued support will train future leaders to expand our understanding of fundamental immunological mechanisms, with implications for major human diseases.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Basic Immunology

PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is the most prominent symptom of osteoarthritis (OA) that profoundly affects the quality of life and daily physical activity of the patients. In the proposed project, we will examine whether enlargement of subchondral bone cavity promote sensory innervation and sensitization of the nociceptive nervous system. Importantly, we will validate whether abnormal bone remodeling induced enlargement of subchondral bone cavity is a novel treatment target for OA pain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surgeon-scientists are in a unique position to facilitate the clinical translation of basic science and clinical effectiveness research discoveries, with the potential for significant improvements in patient care. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung diseases, such as those caused by gene mutations, result in significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. The advent of stem cell discoveries and regenerative medicine presents new opportunities to improve our understanding of these diseases and to develop new treatment approaches. Here we propose a Program Project Grant, composed of 4 integrated projects and 2 cores, whose goal is advancing the latest discoveries in stem cell biology, human organoid culture models, and gene editing to better understand and develop new treatments for genetic lung diseases.

PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE Despite the many recent advances in precision oncology, significant challenges remain in extending the benefits of this remarkable class of drugs to all cancer patients, particularly those with rare mutations in common cancer genes, those with rare cancers, and those from ethnic backgrounds that are not sufficiently represented in current precision oncology datasets. The investigators in our multi-disciplinary team will apply their complementary expertise to investigate these questions by leveraging the extensive observational data that can be accessed through a large, international clinico-genomic cancer registry called AACR Project GENIE.

PROJECT_TITLE: Leveraging Observational (Real World) Data to Advance Precision Oncology

PHR: PROJECT 1 NARRATIVE Research in precision cancer medicine requires large databases of molecular tumor characteristics linked to clinical information on responses to treatment. Efforts such as the AACR Project GENIE have gathered data on tumor characteristics for tens of thousands of patients, but the usefulness of this information has been limited by the difficulty of extracting and analyzing information on cancer outcomes from electronic health records, typically recorded as unstructured text. We will (1) evaluate a framework for medical record review to derive cancer endpoints by comparing framework-based annotations to traditional clinical trial endpoints; (2) develop cross-institutional artificial intelligence and natural language processing models to extract endpoints from physician reports automatically; and (3) evaluate a method for analyzing the resulting endpoints in the context of real-world data biases that may correlate with clinical risk.

PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE Despite significant advances in cancer biology and clinical oncology, race- and ethnicity-based disparities in cancer outcomes remain a long-standing challenge. We propose to investigate how race, ethnicity, and genetic ancestry contribute to cancer outcomes in the largest publicly available registry of diverse cancer patients.

PHR: PROJECT 3 NARRATIVE This project will leverage the large AACR Project GENIE clinical-genomic database to determine clinical outcomes of subsets of patients receiving immunotherapy and patients with rare mutations, and to evaluate the contribution of co-mutations, neoantigens, and expression signatures to response outliers. Findings will be incorporated into a clinical decision-making tool in OncoKB, a recognized resource for cancer precision medicine practitioners.

PHR: CORE A NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this core is to ascertain “real world” clinical outcomes with rigor and reproducibility and to ensure that the inferences made from the resulting observational databases are reliable and reported with transparency. We accomplish this by coordinating curation and interpretation efforts to apply PRISSMM, a tumor-site agnostic data model to specification of oncologic outcomes from EHR data. Broad availability of high- quality tumor genomic data linked to treatment exposures and survival outcomes will propel further advances in precision oncology and translational research.

PHR: CORE B NARRATIVE The Molecular Pathology and Bioinformatics Core will perform deep molecular characterization of tumors collected from patients across all participating cancer centers to identify DNA- and RNA-based features that correlate with clinical outcomes. In line with the goals of the Research Projects, we will select and prioritize tumors representing underrepresented populations, subclasses of patients who have received immunotherapy, and ERBB2 and BRAF fusion cancer types, and that benefit from coordinated efforts across many institutions to adequately study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Leukodystrophies are a collection of rare genetic disorders that are predominantly fatal, progressive disorders of childhood with few targeted therapeutic options. Exciting recent advances, including gene therapy development for adrenoleukodystrophy and metachromatic leukodystrophy, underscore the critical need for continued innovation and a pipeline of future translational researchers interested in rare diseases. Leveraging resources within the Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network Global Leukodystrophy Initiative Clinical Trials Network (GLIA-CTN) and educational expertise of the Institute for Translational Medicine and Therapeutics Education (ITMAT Ed) program, we propose an education program, the Predoctoral Preparatory Program (P3), targeting junior research coordinators within the GLIA-CTN which will (1) provide a curriculum related to responsible conduct of research and (2) prepare the next generation of physician scientists in translational research through professional development workshops and mentorship.

ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Summer Research Fellowship Program for Podiatric Medical Students seeks to increase the number of podiatric medical students entering careers in biomedical sciences. This is especially important in the field of diabetes, as foot pathology is one of the most common complications affecting the 29 million people in the United States living with the disease. Students who have participated in the program have produced numerous peer- reviewed publications, research abstracts, awards and grant funding in contribution to diabetes-related research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To address the glaring lack of diversity at the highest levels of infectious disease research—and with the biomedical research community in general—PIs at Rice University and Houston Community College (HCC) will Augment Community College Education to Leverage Experiential Research and Advance Training Equity (ACCELERATE) by providing enhanced opportunities to HCC students from historically underrepresented groups. Specifically, the ACCELERATE Program will consist of professional development seminars; literature review training; laboratory modules for technical skill development; mentored summer research internships in infectious disease labs at Rice University and the Texas Medical Center (TMC); and mentorship from the Program PIs, HCC faculty, TMC investigators, and postdocs and graduate students. Given these opportunities and the support of their mentor and peer networks, students will be well-positioned to transfer to four-year universities, pursue research at those institutions, gain entrance to top graduate schools, and ultimately attain leadership positions to increase the diversity of the national biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) This biotechnology research center project establishes a national resource that will provide cutting edge technologies to enable the use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) devices running at ultrahigh magnetic fields of 10.5T and 16.4T as sensitive tools for basic and clinical research. Combining these unique MRI capabilities with non-MR methods of advanced electrophysiology and multiphoton optical imaging system, a first of its kind, will be used to provide novel insights into brain function and connectivity from single neurons to the whole brain. Clinical research will benefit from the development of advanced methods that report on physiological and molecular processes where UHF will provide increased sensitivity assessing disease progression and evaluating treatment response. Specific engineering, physics and image reconstruction strategies will be implemented to realize the full potential of UHF systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The training program has as its primary objective to prepare MD, MD/PhD, and PhD postdoctoral fellows for productive careers in the hematology research workforce. There is a particular need to expand the number of scientists and physician-scientists trained in research in the field of hematology because of its direct relevance to some of the most common human medical conditions, including abnormalities of immune cells, vascular diseases, disorders of blood clotting, and sickle cell disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying and cataloging the occurrence of structural variants (SVs)—including deletions, insertions, duplications, and inversions—in human chromosomes is essential for comprehensively understanding genetic disease risk and developing precision medicine approaches to mitigate disease. However, despite significant advances in long-read sequencing technology and genome assembly methods, many SVs can still not be assembled accurately, and improved methods and resources are required for genotyping, ascertaining functional relevance of SVs, and associations of SVs with specific phenotypic traits. We will capitalize on our combined expertise to develop the most comprehensive resource of human genome structural variation and significantly improve methods for SV detection, characterization and phenotype association to aid researchers and clinicians in understanding the role of SVs in genetic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergency medicine and hospital medicine are the foundation of hospital-based care for acute heart, lung, and blood disorders yet are underrepresented in scientific career development efforts. Drawing on institutional strengths in research training, scientific career development, and learning health systems, we propose the Vanderbilt Interdisciplinary Hospital-based Systems of Care Research Training Program (VISTA) for postdoctoral fellows. To improve hospital-based care in NHLBI priority areas, VISTA will provide rigorous mentored research training in discovery, evidence translation, data science, policy and epidemiology, and operations research, incorporating stakeholder engagement and health equity throughout the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying modifiable prenatal and early life risk factors is crucial for developing strategies to prevent childhood asthma. While individual birth cohort studies have identified several asthma-related genetic, personal and environmental risk factors, these studies were mainly limited to homogeneous cohorts and modest sample sizes. We propose establishing a children's allergy and asthma data hub (The Children's Allergy and Asthma Data Repository, or “CADRE”) to ensure enduring access for the scientific community to allergy and asthma birth cohort data.

PHR: Project Narrative Since 2019, the Cancer Prevention and Control (CAPAC) Research Training Program has organized mentored cancer research experiences in Puerto Rico for master-level and health professional students from diverse racial/ethnic backgrounds, with a focus on Hispanic populations. This unique program has resulted in successful scientific outcomes for its trainees, including cancer research experiences along the cancer control continuum, conference presentations, publications, and acceptance into doctoral programs. During the renewal period, CAPAC will increase the number of trainees, integrate new topics in the educational activities, and continue the development of the next generation of cancer researchers by mentoring and fostering participants and providing them the knowledge and skills to pursue a doctoral degree and/or academic and professional careers in cancer prevention and control research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Pediatric Hematology and Transfusion Medicine Multidisciplinary Research Training Award (PHTMMRT) at Children's National is a rigorous 2- to 3-year mentored program of career development and research training for post-doctoral pediatric subspeciality trainees who have demonstrated potential for and interest in pursuing research careers particularly in the areas of red cell biology, and sickle cell disease, cell therapies/immunobiology, infection/inflammation and coagulation/vascular biology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic injury is the leading cause of death for Americans between the ages of 1 and 44, accounting for nearly half of all deaths in this age group, as well as significant long-term complications for many who survive, and the highly-specialized surgical care available at Level 1 trauma centers substantially improves patient survival and recovery from traumatic injury when compared to less specialized treatment. Further advances in the treatment of traumatic injury will require trauma surgeons to actively pursue the research necessary to make new discoveries and develop new systems of care, which is facilitated by adding formal preparation in the methods and application of scientific investigation to their clinical training. The program described herein provides the methodological and experiential groundwork essential for addressing this need.
PROJECT_TERMS: Fellowship;Trauma Research
PROJECT_TITLE: Trauma Research Fellowship

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Anesthesiology has an increasing impact on overall patient care and outcomes through a comprehensive perioperative care model. However, anesthesiology research to improve perioperative patient outcomes is limited by the number of well-trained scientists and physicians devoted to anesthesiology research. This T32 program is aimed at increasing the number of well-trained anesthesiology researchers by supporting a formal training program in anesthesiology research at Washington University, which has one of the largest anesthesiology research programs in the US.

PROJECT_TITLE: TRAINING PROGRAM IN ANESTHESIOLOGY RESEARCH

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE “The BrainCellQTL consortium: QTL mapping in the human brain at the single cell level” is a collaborative U24 Center application that integrates and aligns the efforts of four sites (Sage Bionetworks, Seven Bridges, University of Toronto, and Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai) to construct a cell type-specific quantitative trait locus atlas for gene expression and epigenome regulation in the human brain. This resource will be shared with the scientific community and will be extensively utilized to derive genetically driven gene dysregulation in serious mental and neurological disorders.

The goal of the Weill Cornell/Rockefeller/Sloan Kettering Tri- Institutional MD-PhD Program is to identify, train, and mentor a diverse group of outstanding individuals to become effective clinician-scientists and future leaders in biomedical research and patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will leverage the University of Pennsylvania's open-source platform, Pennsieve, to create an international Epilepsy Data Ecosystem, a resource to accelerate collaborative research on Human Epilepsy. This repository will take in and share high-impact, multi-modal data sets from leading clinical centers and make them easy to discover, share and analyze to improve patient care and develop new technologies. The project replaces ieeg.org, and prospectively take in data from contributors around the world, as a scalable and sustainable repository for epilepsy research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aging population is increasing at an unprecedented rate at the US and worldwide. Aging impacts the severity and susceptibility of acute and chronic lung disease, however the mechanisms responsible for cellular aging and age-related susceptibility to disease are complex and incompletely understood. This integrated and multidisciplinary training program provides critical and structured guidance for postdoctoral trainees who will be at the forefront advances in biology of aging and pulmonary science.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in the Biology of Aging and Lung Diseases

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Northwestern University Lung Sciences Training Program (NULSTP) will build on its success in training the next generation of physician-scientists and scientists through mentored research that incorporates rigorous training in advanced technologies. The NULSTP trains young investigators to use systems biology models of lung disease derived from patients’ clinical and molecular data to make predictions about disease pathobiology and to causally test these predictions using murine models of disease to advance our goals of reducing the burden of lung disease and promoting lung health. Trainees will continue to publish novel science, attain career development awards, and transition to independent research careers to become future leaders in lung-related translational and basic research.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Lung Sciences

This proposal applies high-throughput technologies to map the locations of protein-DNA interactions in human cells, an essential factor in genome function. The data and tools proposed will be a genomic resource crucial for basic research and disease studies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal cancers constitute the plurality of cancer deaths in the United States, yet there remains a pressing need to train the next generation of scientists to conduct GI cancer research in an innovative and productive manner. Leveraging strong support from Columbia University Irving Medical Center and the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center, we have developed a GI Cancer Training Program to identify and recruit a diverse pool of trainees, offer them a rigorous and individualized curriculum, and provide them with research experience in gastrointestinal cancers working with one of our numerous expert and experienced faculty mentor investigators at Columbia University.

PHR: Project Narrative Because of the worsening survival of women with advanced and relapsed endometrial cancer, this P01 grant is focused on targeting replication stress (RS) in order to improve therapeutic outcomes in these patients. Each of the 3 projects focuses on different strategies for targeting RS in endometrial cancer: i) using WEE1 inhibition as monotherapy against uterine serous carcinomas (USC) and other p53-mutated uterine cancers characterized by genomic alterations associated with high RS; ii) using combined ATR and PI3K inhibition to capitalize on concomitant PI3K pathway alterations and genomic alterations associated with high RS in USCs and ARID1A mutated uterine carcinomas; and iii) using ATR and WEE1 inhibitors in combination with immune checkpoint inhibitors to facilitate effective anti-tumor immunity in this disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Targeting Replication Stress and DNA Damage Response in Uterine Cancer

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1 – WEE1 inhibition in uterine serous carcinomas or p53-mutated uterine cancers Molecular features of uterine serous carcinoma (USC) and other p53-mutated uterine cancers, a group of uterine cancers with poor prognoses, suggest that these cancers have high “replication stress”, a state where replication of the DNA is slowed and under stress, and may therefore be particularly vulnerable to drugs that target replication stress like a WEE1 inhibitor. A clinical trial with the WEE1 inhibitor adavosertib previously demonstrated significant clinical activity in USCs. In this project, we seek to advance the care and improve outcomes for individuals with USC or p53-mutated uterine cancers by establishing a better understanding of the mechanisms of replication stress and how replication stress is linked to WEE1 inhibitor sensitivity, leveraging assays of replication stress and WEE1 inhibitor sensitivity in patient-derived organoid model systems, immunohistochemical measures of DNA damage and replication stress in mouse model systems, and biopsy samples taken from patients on a clinical trial with the WEE1 inhibitor ZN-c3.

PHR: Project Narrative Genomic alterations associated with high replication stress (RS) and concomitant PI3K pathway alterations are prevalent in uterine serous and ARID1A-mutated uterine cancers (UC). Based on preliminary data supporting synergistic antitumor activity of combined ATR and PI3K inhibition, this proposal aims to investigate the therapeutic potential and biologic activity of this novel therapeutic strategy in UC, whose incidence and death rates are both significantly increasing in the United States.
