PHR: NARRATIVE Bipolar disorder is a devastating illness - its burden exceeds $202 billion a year in direct treatment, societal and family costs. With no known cure and limited therapeutic options, 50% of patients attempt suicide at least once and the disease is poorly understood; our ENIGMA Bipolar Initiative offers a new, cost-effective, innovative global approach - a new source of power to unblock this logjam - by merging resources, imaging and genomic data, capital infrastructure and talents of leading BD centers from 15 countries across the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Over half a million children undergo removal of tonsils and adenoids (‘adenotonsillectomy’ or AT) every year, primarily for the treatment of sleep disordered breathing (SDB). Two serious issues impact AT candidacy assessments in children, which include the lack of (i) mechanistic understanding of how AT impacts SDB outcomes, (ii) and objective indicators for the magnitude of benefit from AT. By addressing these gaps using a novel biomarker of brain activation, we aim to reduce unnecessary surgeries, increase objectivity, improve disparities, and aid shared decision making related to the most common surgery performed in children under 15 years of age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is making use of computers to analyze data from hospitalized patients with respiratory disease including COVID-19. We want to develop methods to identify patterns in the patient data which predict who is at risk for respiratory failure and may need mechanical ventilation. We have a very strong team of doctors and researchers who work closely together, covering all aspects of the proposed research, which we hope will help us improve the care of critically ill patients in hospitals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research elucidates the neural mechanisms underlying flexible decision making in environments with real- world complexity. Our projects document how nonhuman primate subjects cope with real world complexity by combining the use of working memory, adaptive regulation of exploration and attentional prioritization to relevant environmental dimensions. Our projects will identify which brain areas in the frontal – striatal network realize these subcomponent processes and how specific inhibitory cell classes in these brain areas support flexible decision making in the primate brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In this project we will assess how temperature impacts selective and stochastic alterations to WNV populations during systemic mosquito infection. We also will explore how virus particle aggregates and infection of individual cells by multiple WNV genotypes may influence the amount and type of genetic diversity that is maintained in the virus population. This project leverages over 15 years’ worth of WNV and ZIKV research and makes innovative use of new molecular tools that we have developed as part of this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Malaria vaccines capable of completely preventing infection by Plasmodium, the parasite which causes malaria, in non-endemic regions have not shown the same high-level protection when tested in endemic regions. While it is well known that active or prior Plasmodium exposure impacts the immune system in endemic regions, a comprehensive assessment of how these conditions affect vaccination or how even to measure this effect are lacking due to the inability to access critical sites of the immune system such as the liver and bone marrow. Here, we will overcome this by using two non-human primate models that mimic malaria disease in humans and permit comprehensive tissue sampling, and integrate these with human clinical trial samples to build a more complete understanding of how previous malaria exposure impacts vaccine performance and strategies to build the first protective malaria vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) is a significant cause of epilepsy related mortality with an especially high rate (1 in 150) in patients who are refractory to current pharmacotherapies. It is unknown why patients fail to autoresuscitate (or recover) and ultimately die of SUDEP. Here, we will determine the mechanisms that contribute to autoresuscitation failure in a preclinical model of SUDEP.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to study advanced detector designs and scanner configurations that offer improved performance for Total-Body time-of-flight (TOF) PET and to judge the merits of these choices by their impact on a variety of potential total-body PET clinical/research applications. Our studies will include development of enabling technology for two TOF detector concepts that can be scaled to a full system: one (with LYSO) emphasizing TOF resolution and the other (with BGO) emphasizing higher intrinsic sensitivity. These studies will inform Monte Carlo simulations of scanner models that will be correlated with human studies performed with the PennPET Explorer scanner based on current technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The robotic platform we propose has the potential to provide a safer, more accessible, and potentially painless alternative to standard colonoscopy for patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Ulcerative Colitis or Crohn's disease)-a disease that impacts the lives of over three million Americans, who are at a 6-fold increased risk for post-colonoscopy adverse events when compared to their non-lBD counterparts. The platform uses magnetic actuation, intelligent closed-loop control, and integrated assistive autonomy of our diagnostic and therapeutic magnetic flexible endoscope (MFE) to facilitate intuitive endoscopist-directed motion under precise control with a novel colon-visualization-index (CVI) that provides feedback to the endoscopist with estimates of the portion of colon lumen successfully imaged to maximize the yield of exam. We propose the first in-human study of a magnetically actuated robotic platform for colonoscopy and the first in-human demonstration of intelligent control with assistive autonomy using magnetic fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We study tumor suppressor miR-125b therapeutics for traumatic brain injury (TBI) using the lateral fluid percussion-induced TBI model in young adult rats (10-11 weeks old) of both sexes. This proposal will show that intravenous (i.v.) miR-125b mimic decreases target genes (Mknk2, Alpk3, Neu1, Bap1) in blood (leukocytes, platelets), endothelial cells and brain (neurons, astrocytes, microglia) to improve TBI outcome: miR-125b mimic→ Mknk2↓ Alpk3↓ Neu1↓ Bap1↓ in blood cells, endothelial cells and brain cells → improvement of multiple pathological and behavioral outcomes after TBI. The combined use of intravenous miR-125b mimic and PEG-liposomes to treat TBI is novel and can be translated to treat human TBI, since i.v. route is translatable for human use and the PEG-liposomes used for in vivo miR drug delivery is FDA-approved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative African Americans with type 2 diabetes is a substantial public health problem. A novel approach to diabetes self- management that capitalizes on the strong family culture among African Americans is proposed with an in-person group of individuals with type 2 diabetes and their family members to be used as a way to promote adherence to diabetes self-management and to facilitate behavior changes and health outcomes among African Americans with type 2 diabetes while improving healthy lifestyle behaviors among family members. This study will contribute to the development of family dyad-focused intervention as an effective approach with long-term goal of improving glycemic control and health-related quality of life for African Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH REVELANCE (Narrative) Our bodies tissues are where most pathogens are encountered (SARS-CoV2, influenza, HSV, candida) and where the majority of tumors arise. Immune protection of barrier tissues is required to combat pathogen infection and limit tumor development however, simultaneous regulatory mechanisms prevent adverse auto- inflammation, and autoimmunity at these sites. In this proposed work, we seek to define key regulatory mechanisms that govern this balanced tissue immunity, required for human health.
